name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The first item of order of the day is the report by Sander Loones on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on Banking Union — Annual Report 2017 (2017/2072 (INI)) (A8-0019/2018).

name: Sander Loones
text: rapporteur. — (NL) Thank you, Mr President. It's early in the morning. I'm a good sleeper. I'm lucky in that area. I sleep fairly easily, but there are people who sleep less well, who worry at night because they feel insecure, including about their future, and who wonder if their savings are safe. It is our job to take these concerns seriously, to address them, and, where necessary, to remedy them. After all, people have not yet forgotten the deep wounds of the euro crisis, how their savings have been put at risk. We all said that this must never happen again. That is the question we are discussing today in this report. Have we kept our word? Will this never happen again? Have we elaborated rules that have made our banking system more robust, strengthened when banks go bankrupt? Let us start with the honest answer: yes, we did. The system has become stronger and more robust, because we also made the fair and correct analysis at and after that financial crisis, which said that there were too few rules, which allowed bankers to build up too high risks. We dealt with that. We have put more rules on the table and introduced them. Secondly, we have also reversed logic. It used to be that large shareholders, large banks' bond holders, went with profits when things went well, but the losses passed on to the taxpayer when things went wrong. We reversed that logic. What makes this report special is that we have not only seen the rules, but also seen the application of the rules, for the first time in the European Union and a number of different countries, with varying success. We saw what happened in Latvia this weekend, but last year we saw mainly the cases in Spain and Italy, where the spirit of the rules is somewhat more respected than in the other case. I think that in Italy, for example, we have seen a more creative interpretation of banking rules. I think that this is the European disease, ladies and gentlemen. We actually have better rules, but we don't always apply them. We ensure that additional measures are taken, but if there are loopholes, they are not completely closed. I think we should start with that, finally doing what we agreed. That we would also apply the rules on the table effectively. But no, then you see that in the European debate there is practically the idea that, by definition, the easiest way to solve problems is by going to solidarity them, by spreading them. I'm the daddy of three young children. When our daughter Suzanne does something wrong, I address her, and she must pay for it. If I would raise my children not in Flemish but in European terms, I would not only have to address her, but also her brothers, Tuur and Cas, who actually did nothing wrong. That is pretty much the logic that you see in the banking system, that we must show solidarity, that Member States that have done nothing wrong are by definition asked to show solidarity with Member States that do go wrong. I don't think that's right. I think we should first ask for those Member States to take responsibility to put the accounts in order before we start to solidarize matters. That is why, in all fairness, I sometimes get a little nervous when I see dossiers on the European table, for example the European Deposit and Guarantee Fund. Today, there are national funds which are competent to regulate where people's savings could be jeopardised up to EUR 100 000. Europe, the European Commission in particular, is now saying that these national jars are too small, that we should with a single large European pot, which would make banks and savers here in northern Europe a guarantee for savers in southern Europe. I think we should be careful about this anyway. I think it is a good system if we solidarity risks, but on condition that the Member States first limit their risks themselves. There is still some work to be done in this area, in particular in southern Europe.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Loones for his annual report on the Banking Union. It has provided us with an excellent account of how much has so far been achieved since the last financial crisis and of what remains to be done in the future.  As you know, the completion of the Banking Union is one of the Commission’s highest priorities and we very much welcome the attention and engagement Parliament shows in its annual report for 2017. Major steps have been taken towards Banking Union and results have been achieved since the same debate took place last year, but we agree that we are not done yet.  First, regarding the banking sector, good progress has been made in the negotiations on the November 2016 banking package, which will strengthen the prudential framework and increase banks’ ability to absorb losses in times of crisis – without the help of taxpayers’ money. EU banks are significantly stronger than they were before the crisis, thanks to their own efforts to adjust their business models and also thanks to the regulatory reforms we introduced and to better supervision. However, non-performing-loan ratios remain high in some Member States. To address this, the Commission – as announced in the First Progress Report on the Reduction of Non-Performing Loans in Europe, in January 2018 – will adopt a comprehensive package tackling non-performing loans this spring. The package will focus on requiring banks to put aside sufficient means to cover losses if new loans become non-performing; tackling delays in debt recovery; opening up secondary markets; and, lastly, clarifying with a blueprint how EU countries can set up national asset-management companies if they so decide. Bank exposure to sovereigns is another area where the Commission shares Parliament’s view: this problem has multiple implications, including the financial stability and international dimension. Regarding financial technology (fintech), the Commission fully agrees with the need to ensure a level playing field for all market participants, based on the ‘same activity, same rule’ principle. In line with Parliament’s call, the Commission will adopt on 7 March a communication on fintech, in the form of an Action Plan, which will also include a number of initiatives to strengthen the cyber resilience of the EU financial sector. Coming to my second point, on the institutional setting of Banking Union, this is an area where more needs to be done. Recent experience will help to improve further the practical application of the rules, as well as coordination among the Commission, the Single Resolution Board, the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the European Banking Authority. Overall, the two pillars of Banking Union (supervision and resolution) are working well and, as numbers demonstrate, have helped further to reduce risks in the banking sector. But for Banking Union to deliver its full potential it must be complete. For this reason, the Commission welcomes the report’s call to complete the Banking Union with common deposit insurance arrangements, and we are committed to working with Parliament and the Council to advance rapidly on the European Deposit Insurance Scheme. Quick progress is also needed to build up a readily available common backstop for a single resolution fund, in order to increase its credibility. These are just some of the areas highlighted in your report, and we are looking forward to pursuing work in these areas with you.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, I think it is very good that the Banking Union Report has been successfully established as one of the routine exercises of the European Parliament. This time around, on many issues related to the functioning of the Banking Union, we have had the opportunity to express ourselves for the first time. I am thinking here of the actions undertaken by the European Institutions to fight non-performing loans or the recent bank resolution cases. But this year we also have a chance to move forward on legislation. We have received from the Commission a proposal for a fiscal backstop for the Single Resolution Fund. We have also the Commission communication on the Banking Union that, among others, intends to relaunch the discussion on the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS), the missing pillar of the Banking Union, and to test a new approach to the design of the system. And of course, the Banking Package is still under discussion. But this is also the moment for those Member States that do not share a common currency yet to consider joining the Banking Union as soon as possible. It is a shock-absorption mechanism and also comes with governance arrangements that help deal with home host issues. The benefits of belonging to such a system would be particularly pronounced in Central Europe, where Member States are host countries, hosting a huge number of branches and subsidiaries of institutions that actually come from the Banking Union area. Also, at a time of questions on the future of the Union and the risks of increased fragmentation, a broad membership of the Banking Union would be a way of containing supervisory divergence and fragmentation and of involving all Member States in a common project that fosters resilience and financial stability.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, I would like to congratulate Sander Loones and thank him and welcome the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. There is no doubt that progress has been made: the European banking system is more robust than it was, but it would be illusory to think that it is safe from a future crisis until the banking union is complete. The third pillar, though indispensable, is not in place. The initial implementation of the resolution regime raises many questions. It will be necessary to make full transparency and draw conclusions to improve it. And I am not talking about the undercapitalization of certain banks, doubtful debts, sovereign debt, insufficient risk-sharing and the need for better coordination among authorities, not to mention the challenges of cyber attacks, which require increased attention and significant investments in security.

name: Bernd Lucke
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I would also like to thank the rapporteur for a truly excellent report on the banking union, which I believe is partly misread in this House — at least as far as EDIS is concerned. He has a very different language from previous reports on the banking union. It is not called for EDIS, Commissioner, as you have just said wrongly, but it is made quite clear that the Banking Union fulfils important tasks in its two existing pillars, but that, at the same time, we do have mechanisms in the area of deposit protection that are already very sensibly designed in the area of deposit protection. The objective is that we have the Deposit Guarantee Directive, which allows national deposit guarantee schemes to lend to distressed other deposit guarantee schemes in crisis, but does not oblige them to do so. With this design, the banking union is complete. It is completely wrong to constantly say that we still need to complete them. It is downright dangerous if we were to oblige national deposit guarantee schemes to accept a flow of resources in crisis situations, because it is precisely this that could lead to a bank run in the helping deposit guarantee schemes, could lead to a loss of confidence that encourages savers to withdraw their deposits. The EDIS deposit guarantee scheme could therefore create additional risks, and it is therefore a wrong step to move forward in this direction.

name: Thierry Cornillet
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, rapporteur, Mr Vice-President, banking union is a young but very good invention. It is worth remembering the fundamental objectives of ensuring the soundness of banks and their ability to withstand future crises, to avoid recourse to taxpayers' money when these banks are in difficulty, to harmonise the rules and, last but not least, to strengthen the financial stability of the euro area and, by means of consequently, that of the European Union. The establishment of the Single Monitoring Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism is recent, and is therefore improved. In particular, there are margins for progress in terms of transparency, predictability or readability of decisions. The third pillar of this banking union is the European deposit insurance system. Work on it is necessary, even if it is necessary to take the time to think about it. It is useful to arrive at a system that encourages banks to virtue — the rapporteur pointed out earlier — and ensures the stability of the system for the benefit of all. I would also point out that the banking union is open even to those who do not yet have the euro as their currency. Some members who are not yet part of the euro area hesitate, I do not hesitate to tell them: come, you are welcome to take an active part in strengthening financial stability and thus, consequently, the stability of the European Union as a whole.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the ‘too big to fail’ problem of the European banks remains unchanged. Our banking system has not changed as much as the crisis showed it was needed. On the contrary, we are in a period of regulatory rollback at international and EU level, lowering standards in financial regulation. In this context, the Greens strongly support decisive steps towards risk reduction that should go hand-in-hand with risk-sharing, and we see with concern that this is actually not happening. 2017 was the year when we saw obstacles to resolvability of the Venetian banks and the first resolution under the EU framework, the popular case which shows that further transparency is clearly needed. We would like to thank Mr Loones for the good work, because the Annual Report on the Banking Union addresses some of our concerns: concerns with resolvability and with mis-selling; good wording on EDIS, which we believe are very important; concerns that our Group has traditionally had with shadow banking, for instance. We believe that this is a good report and we would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation and we will vote in favour.

name: Marco Valli
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too wanted to thank the rapporteur Mr Loones for doing a fair amount of work. Unfortunately, for us, there remain very difficult points to accept, in general on banking union, starting with the first pillar on supervision: there are clear gaps in supervision on the part of the system of banking supervision and the Commission should remedy it. I'm talking about the second and third tier assets, derivatives, which are a market equal to almost 12 times NPLs — we talk about 6 800 billion, we get to 453 billion notionals. The Commission in my opinion should take a conscience examination and understand if the problem is only NPLs, and therefore credit, and not to attack even what is a systemic problem, namely the problem related to the asset market level 2 and level 3, because there are the interests of the big business banks and there is the real systemic risk. As for pillar two, the resolution, we have seen that bail in leads savers and confidence in the financial system to be uncredible. So a system of guaranteeing all deposits should also be created, so that savers are and feel truly protected, which the banking union today is failing to do, and therefore there is a need for this. Plus, you have to stop talking about the consequences of banking crises, but go and talk about the causes. The only way is to apply a real and real bank separation by reopening the project of BSR, namely banking structural reform, which has been forgotten and should instead be resumed.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission. Supervision and resolution are today the two pillars of the Banking Union. The rapporteur has worked out this very well in the report. The third pillar — deposit protection — is controversial; we have already been able to witness this here today in the context of this discussion. But there are large Member States that believe that a systemic reduction of high risks in the bank balance sheets of EU institutions should take place before a joint deposit guarantee — i.e. risk reduction before risk-sharing. I would like to endorse this request. While an agreement on deposit protection is still a long way off, banking supervision should work. If I now cite the case of Latvia's third largest bank, the ABV, which is on the verge of collapse after passing the stress test after massive allegations of money laundering and is a case for bank resolution, this does not strengthen confidence in supervision. The fact that this case was not uncovered by the ECB's banking supervision, but by the US tax authorities, does not strengthen confidence. The Banking Union has undoubtedly made the financial sector safer. This is also evident in the Commission's latest progress report on NPL reduction. The inspector has mentioned it. Quotas are still different, but perhaps a proposal from the rapporteur should be adopted and the stress tests of banking supervision should be followed by more consistent measures so that a case like Latvia does not happen in the future.

name: Miguel Viegas
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Mr President, during 2017, once again taxpayers were forced to pay the bailout of the Italian bank, with a massive contribution of 17 billion public money. This money taken directly from the workers' pockets served to save two failed banks and protect their bondholders. In Portugal, taxpayers' money continues to pay for the resolutions of BPN, Banif and Banco Espírito Santo. We have also seen a wave of mergers and the creation of gigantic financial groups, all of which are controlled by foreign groups, that is, all contrary to what was announced by the Banking Union, which was set up to end banks too big to go bankrupt and end the regabofe of public funds to pay for the beans for speculation and financial irresponsibility. For the CFP, the Banking Union was designed to strengthen the role of finance and to deprive national states of any capacity to intervene in the financial system. We know today that supervision is a farce and that the resolution is not credible. Our proposal is very clear: only public control of banking can put the financial system at the service of the economy and development.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Dank u wel, mijnheer de Voorzitter. Ik zou allereerst in onze gedeelde taal Sander Loones als rapporteur willen bedanken voor zijn verslag. I will turn to English as I have put away my prepared short intervention, and I would like to take up some words that we heard from the Commissioner, which are of course well appreciated. He mentioned that the two pillars of the Banking Union are working well – and they are, but not fully. I do think that the situation that has come to light, for example in Latvia – brought to our attention by the US rather than European supervision – shows that there are also still some blind spots in the first and second pillars. I am not mentioning this to be difficult; I am mentioning this because I know it makes the work on the third pillar more difficult. You have heard from colleagues how controversial the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) proposal is. There is a will to progress, I think, among many in this House, and I welcome in that regard the Commission Communication that we saw at the end of last year, and also the words of the Commission on the initiatives that we can expect on non-performing loans (NPLs) and exposure to sovereigns. I think these are key, especially if at some point we want to move EDIS beyond liquidity support only. But I believe that progress, especially in these two fields, needs to be measurable, proven and concrete, not only on the flow, but also on the stocks, of NPLs. So there is quite a lot of work ahead of us. The spirit is positive and I thank the Commission for that, but it will, I am afraid, take time. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — My question is in the direction of risk reduction. We know that in the event of major failures so far, it is customary for the state to jump in. In the case of small companies, execution is actually carried out relatively quickly and immediately. Do you believe that risk reduction should also support small and medium-sized enterprises in particular, so that they have better liquidity opportunities to implement their business models accordingly?

name: Esther de Lange (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – It is always a pleasure to get a blue card from your own Group. Without going into the detail of the EDIS proposal and the implications for certain Member States and smaller banks, what is clear is that the resolution cases that we have seen taking place in Europe have not all followed the ideal model that we foresaw when we put the legislation into place. That just proves my point that there are still some blind spots in the way that the legislation was meant to be. But I can reassure, in some regards, the colleague from Austria that we are, of course – also in working on the EDIS proposal – aware that the legislation that we make should suit big banks, but also the smaller ones and the particular cases that we have seen in the case of Einlagensicherung in Germany and in Austria.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, banking union is the umbrella of the concept of risk reduction and risk-sharing. Sometimes I have the impression that the balance is imbalanced and that we forget to assess all the efforts that have already been made in terms of risk reduction, including how the European Union is going to integrate new international concepts to enable it to fulfil its commitments, with regard to the absorption of losses — the famous TLAC — or to lower the domestic value of non-performing loans (NPL), on which we expect new proposals. But this annual report today is a meeting point that perhaps allows us to identify three areas where more needs to be done. First, it was said here, the missing pillars. In essence, I identify two, of course, and ten on which no valid proposal can be made unless we advance in parallel on the question of liquidity and the question of loss absorption. But there is also this famous “budgetary support scheme” on which progress could be made with the transformation of the European Stability Mechanism, but we urge you to be vigilant to ensure that this is done according to the Community method, of course. And then there is the question of the link between banking sovereigns and states. We believe that the banking union should allow us to use these famous derogations which allow us to use the profits gained from the existence of the banking union. Finally, a third project opens for us following the Latvian case and the fall of the ABLV bank, which show us how secure and stable banking union cannot be achieved unless we look at the fiscal dimension and in particular the impact of the fight against money laundering on the stability and systemic nature of banks.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. We have an absurd situation after years of financial market reform. Some major banks continue to operate in the market with leverage ratios of only 4% of their balance sheet, while on the other hand — I have looked at this several times in my constituency — smaller institutions that are well off with a debt ratio of 8 -10% are flooded with reporting requirements for the Central Bank, national and European, the supervisor, national and European, of the European Banking Authority and also of the national statistical authorities. These reporting requirements are completely disproportionate to the objective of financial stability. It is therefore right that we are calling here for a uniform European reporting system to ensure that even smaller financial market players can survive after financial market reforms. I would ask you, Commissioner, to help us in the current legislation to launch such a comprehensive European standardised reporting system so that the bureaucratic burden is reduced while achieving the objectives of financial stability.

name: Jörg Meuthen (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. We're talking about the banking union today. The German government called for banking supervision by the ECB in 2012, which was considered a clever move at the time. Today it has to be said that the German government has failed all along the line. The Banking Union is increasingly becoming a transfer union. The report calls for a safeguarding of bank resolution by the tax authorities. He naughty claims that this avoids recourse to state money. Ladies and gentlemen, you need to explain to me how to secure something fiscally without burdening the tax authorities. The report also calls for the ESM to be transformed into a European Monetary Fund to take over this fiscal hedge. Ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to vote in favour of my amendment and to reject it. It's time to give their colours — against bank bailouts at taxpayers' costs, against European deposit insurance and against the expansion of the banking union into a transfer union.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: — Mr President, the banking union is the area where we have made quite a lot of progress and the European Commission deserves congratulations on persistence in this area. I am sure that we will also find a rational solution for guaranteeing people's bank deposits. What is worrying, however, is the way in which banking regulations are applied by some European banks. It is disturbing to learn from the United States of America about cases of money laundering through European banks and not to learn this from the banking system of the European Union, which we have created. Let us not forget that one billion dollars disappeared from the Republic of Moldova through European banks, without us, here in the European Union, paying attention and clarifying such cases as well.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you very much for this report, which shows us that we have taken many steps forward in the banking union, but at the same time we have not yet finished. We have created the first pillar of joint supervision, but we need to take more appropriate account of the size and complexity of the institutions in the future. We have reduced the number of bad loans by a third since mid-2014, but we need to take further action, as the portfolio of EUR 950 billion is still above pre-crisis levels. We have created the second pillar of joint resolution, but we need to remove existing inconsistencies between state aid rules and EU law. We applied the resolution rules for the first time, but we need to improve the decision on whether a bank will fail or likely to fail. And we have strengthened deposit protection in Europe. But we have not yet completed work on the third pillar, a joint protection. I expect the Council to start EDIS now setting the schedule for risk reduction and risk sharing clearly. It's not about the if anymore, it's just about how. Let's finish the House of the Banking Union in this legislative period!

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President! The European Banking Union has substantially strengthened the institutional and regulatory frameworks since the economic crisis. Equity ratios and liquidity ratios of banks in the euro area have clearly improved. But in some Member States the share of problem loans is far too high. The risks within certain national banking systems are not adequately addressed. In doing so, Member States and the banks themselves have primary responsibility for reducing bad credit. For all regulatory requirements, the costs of banks must not increase beyond measure, with a significant impact on the financing models for small and medium-sized enterprises. The principle of proportionality must be preserved. However, facilitations are necessary for banks with simple business models. The diversity of our European banks remains a stable basis for the competitiveness of our financial systems on a global scale.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, the report is welcome. I want to congratulate the rapporteur and I want to refer to something that the rapporteur said. Of course, the financial crisis is still being felt. Let us ask ourselves whether banks take too big risks or too low risks. But the rapporteur also talked about big winnings in the banking system and bonuses and all sorts of prizes. Banks do not take risks for SMEs. SMEs are still unable to take credit and are decapitalised. Unfortunately, banks take risks giving such income to employees, above average, with the highest earnings in the banking system. I believe that what you said must, Commissioner, (of course, progress has been made) happen. It is not enough to have regulations here, it is very important that they also apply. How do we guarantee deposits? There is a big gap in some banks between how much a loan costs and how much interest is given on a deposit. And they are not guaranteed, indeed, for citizens. We must protect, and I, as a member of the IMCO committee, am thinking about how we protect consumers, SMEs, how we protect citizens. So this is where we have to make progress, because otherwise we're going to step on the spot.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: A heartfelt request to adhere to the temporal regime. We need to consider four projects and proceed to the ballots at 11.30 o'clock.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, because of the economic crisis, trillions of EUR in public money has been allocated to the rescue of banks, burdening the public debt of the states, and all at a time when the funds allocated to tackle unemployment were scarce. In Greece there were three bank recapitalisations that increased public debt and socialised banks' losses, since they rescued the shareholders of the banks, many of whom were foreign shareholders. In fact, the third memorandum again sold the banks to private individuals instead of a lentil plate, resulting in a loss of at least EUR 30 billion and, if that were not enough, the banks that were rescued are now attacking the depositors themselves, the citizens themselves, who rescued them, who unfortunately have red loans and are now activating electronic auctions in Greece, resulting in the crows snatch the houses of the Greeks. It's unacceptable. This situation must not continue. The Greek people will not allow the crows to snatch the houses of the Greeks.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, without the European deposit-guarantee scheme, without the third pillar, there is no banking unification. The European economy and the European system are not shielded against a future crisis. In this respect, the completion of the third pillar, which is positive for the citizens, the European perspective and small and medium-sized enterprises, is lagging dangerously because there are a number of Member States within the Council, the Netherlands, Germany, a small minority, but very strong, which essentially puts veto. Because in the European Parliament too, there are objections and objections from the right and extreme right sides of the political spectrum. But we must move on because that is in the interests of the citizens. Significant steps have been taken in reducing risk. Steps must also be taken in the reciprocity of risk. European integration cannot be a 'la kart', it must also move towards the European deposit guarantee scheme.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Mr President, the Eurogroup's latest decisions with the signature of the Syriza government are clear: 11 000 auctions in Greece alone this year. Banking Union means further capital strengthening of banks, which in Greece means three memoranda, redundancies and dramatic reductions in wages and pensions without end, even after the formal expiry of the memorandum, now with the loss of popular housing and the first housing, with the aim of recovering bank funds, with thousands of electronic auctions and sales of loans to fund crows with one purpose only: to fund viable (see large) companies. Another huge theft of popular property for capital. This need of the system is so pressing that popular resistance to auctions is punished as a peculiar crime, hit with tear gas and riot police, as yesterday in Athens. Let the Greek Government and the European Union know: the people are not going to back down. Unconditional protection of popular housing, not to the blackmail of banks and the state!

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, congratulations to Mr Loones on his report. I have just three observations to make. Firstly, the last pillar of banking union needs to be done. I agree with Mr Karas that it is how it is done, and I fully back the approach of Esther de Lange when she spoke to the House about the necessity of having risk-sharing and risk reduction at the same time. This has to be done in a phased way. We have made progress, and it remains to be done in terms of the last issue. My second remark is in relation to NPLs. It is really important that we resolve this issue, because without resolving this issue, we will stop lending to the real economy, to households, to SMEs, and the longer we put it off, the longer it takes for real growth and investment to occur in our economies. In my own country, we have a significant problem with NPLs in some of our banks, which have to be resolved. We also need a system which works within a code that the ECB have set, which is fair and equitable while at the same time recognising the necessity to resolve this issue. We do need more progress on insolvency laws across Europe, more judicial guidance, and we also need a code that is in place for all Member States of the eurozone.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, if you do not maintain order at home, then you should not be surprised if your house is managed by strangers. This fully applies to the European Banking Union. Two weeks ago, the US Financial Crimes Enforcement Network imposed sanctions on ABLV Bank, the third-largest bank in my country, Latvia, by prohibiting it from opening and maintaining a correspondent account in the United States. ABLV was under European Central Bank supervision. Neither the Latvian regulator nor the European Central Bank tried to check the accuracy of the charges. Moreover, after the bank had such difficulties, they helped to push back into the EDIS. The bank was forced to announce self-liquidation. Hundreds of Latvians lost their jobs. Dear colleagues, the authorities of another country can destroy large EU banks by a mere statement of suspicion. Such a situation is unacceptable. The European Union must protect its interests and the interests of European businesses. We need the European Union and European banking as a real thing.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the report. I will focus on just two points. This report takes stock of the issue of NPLs, which is mainly a problem for banks but, as noted in the report, it is also a matter of Member States' policies, but also of policies at European level, so as to avoid a further overgrowth of this problem. Now I move on to the next issue we have been discussing for some time, the Banking Union. Ladies and gentlemen, we agreed a banking union many years ago on three pillars. We applied the two. The timing of the implementation of the pillars was intended to respond to those legitimate concerns of the Member States who said that we should not have excessive transfer of risks. Now there are technical reasons not to apply the bank guarantee. To the Commission: Mr Dombrovskis, what are the real reasons - and not the technical ones - which prevent the implementation of the third pillar?

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me once again thank Mr Loones for his excellent report and for today’s debate. The debate shows once again that we agree on the importance of the Banking Union in order to ensure a robust and stable financial system where banks are able to play their role of lending to the economy and helping to stimulate further economic growth.  To achieve this common goal, we should move from our current positions and make every effort to find solutions that could accommodate all interested stakeholders. As we have emphasised a number of times, we need to move with risk-sharing and risk-reduction hand—in—hand.  Several colleagues raised issues relating to the ABLV Bank, and I think it has exposed certain weakness in a banking union. In recent years we have substantially strengthened the EU’s anti-money laundering (AML) framework, whereas the enforcement of this framework remains largely national. So there we must really see what we can do more at European level as regards AML enforcement. As has been said several times, also by the Commission, we need to take advantage of this favourable economic moment to complete the Banking Union. This is the only way to ensure that the overall economic and monetary union is completed as well and is strong enough to cope with a future crisis. We count on your efforts and support to help move this regulatory agenda forwards.

name: Sander Loones
text: rapporteur. — (NL) Thank you, Mr President. Thank you to colleagues, especially the shadow rapporteurs, for their excellent cooperation and for the interesting debate. I think it's interesting that just about everyone we've heard here says: yes, a lot of work has been done, good work, but there is also work on the shelf. So we still have some business to do. In this respect, it has also become a rather critical report, with a number of incitement to the discussions of the future. If you were to ask me personally what the focus should be on now, I see four points myself. One: I think we need to tighten up our state aid rules more. We learned that from the bank rescues in Italy. Two: we need to work more in the field of supervision. Just recently, we have seen — and has also been referred to repeatedly in this debate — what has happened in Latvia. Three: we need more transparency. There is still a great deal of work to be done in this area too. Finally, four, and this is the most important thing: the rules must be tightened and must not be watered down. In this context, I am looking with more than some interest at what is happening in Italy, for example. There are elections on the agenda this weekend and almost every prominent Italian politician advocates a weakening of the banking rules. That is not the way we should go. The direction we need to take is to go first for responsibility and then for solidarity. I also hear the Commissioner talking about risk sharing and risk reduction, risk-sharing and risk reduction. That's right, but it's wrong at the same time. It should be the other way around. In this Parliament, we should first talk about risk reduction and then about risk sharing. Talk about responsibility first, then about solidarity.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 1 March 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — (PT) The year 2017 saw a well-known story repeated: once again, taxpayers were forced to pay bailouts from private banks. The bailout of Italian banking involved EUR 17 billion of public resources. This money, taken directly from the workers' pockets, served to save two failed banks and protect their bondholders. In Portugal, taxpayers' money continues to pay the resolutions of BPN, Banif or BES. But the much-propagated Banking Union, served to the sweet people with the false promise of an end to the bailouts made with taxpayers' money, actually means much more than the continuation of these same ransom. We have also seen a wave of mergers and the impetus for the monopolistic concentration of the financial sector on a European scale, with the creation of huge financial groups, all of which are controlled by large groups, in the case of Portugal all foreigners. In other words, all contrary to what was announced with the Banking Union, supposedly created to end banks 'too big to bankrupt' and to end the regabofe of public funds to pay for the consequences of speculation and financial irresponsibility. Only public control of banking can place the financial system at the service of the economy and development.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing - The Banking Union, consisting of the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism, is to ensure a reliable and secure banking sector in the European Union. Financial stability in the Union affects the entire economic and economic life and has an impact on each entity. I support the strengthening of the supervision of the banking sector so that, in the event of a threat, the Union can respond in a timely manner and flexibly take the necessary measures. I also consider it essential that a regulation on the European Deposit Protection Fund should be adopted as soon as possible, which will strengthen financial stability and increase the confidence of residents in the financial and banking sectors.

name: Eva Maydell (PPE)
text: in writing. – With all European economies performing considerably better, 2018 has been the first time since 2012 that we can focus on upgrading our economic structure – to equip the Banking Union and the euro area with all the necessary tools in case of a new crisis. It is now time for the economies of the countries of the community to be supported with adequate tools to increase their resilience to future shocks. We want banks to act responsibly and our responsibility as policymaker is to help them by completing the Banking Union. We must not get complacent and rely on good economic times lasting forever. Reaching an agreement on a common financial backstop for the SRF, adopting the financial instruments for reforms and meeting the conditions to set up a European deposit insurance scheme must be top priorities for the EU and finalised before the end of the legislative term of EC and EP. It must be clear that the Banking Union is not an end in itself for the regulators. It is a condition to ensure that taxpayers money is not first in line to pay for banking shocks.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: in writing. — The annual report of the Banking Union discusses the completion of the EMU of the European Economic and Monetary Union. In practice, it is about deepening economic and monetary union towards greater solidarity over bank liabilities and liabilities, which I cannot support. The expansion of solidarity also includes a deposit protection scheme covering the euro area as a whole. The level of problems facing banks varies widely between countries and the average figures in the annual report don't say much about the overall situation. In many countries, such as Italy, huge risks are plusking in the banking sector. Basically, there has been a shift in banking union to bailing out banks with owners' money. In practice, however, the cases that surfaced in 2017 show that there has been no way of getting rid of bank bailouts with taxpayer money. Problem credits need to be thoroughly sorted out and banks” balance sheets cleaned up before a move to a common deposit protection scheme can even be discussed. Without these measures, talk of protecting taxpayer money is empty promises.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item of order of the day is the report drawn up by Emmanuel Maurel on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation in for reported cross-border arrangements (COM (2017) 0335 — C8-0195/2017 — 2017/0138 (CNS)) (A8-0016/2018). At this point, we face a procedural problem — there is no Commissioner Moscovici. I was checking, we were not the ones who accelerated our timetable for the debate, rather the Commissioner is slightly late. Will there be agreement for us to start our debate with the rapporteur's speech hoping that the Commissioner will come?

name: Emmanuel Maurel
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since the last European elections, we have been a few in this Chamber who have devoted ourselves to the fight against tax evasion. It must be recognised that this is not easy, since in four years we have seen a lot of scandals, a lot of revelations and sometimes we feel that our work, our proposals, everything we are trying to do with the Commission do not allow us to move forward very quickly. And that's the truth, unfortunately. But this is also the reason why, as soon as we have small victories, we have to draw a little courage, a little energy and, with this text, it is a small victory — victory certainly modest, but a victory anyway and we must act it. A victory first over white-collar delinquency, fraudsters, professional profit flight planners and those who obviously help them, that is, intermediaries. There is — as you know here, ladies and gentlemen — a real tax optimization industry, with discreet companies, and we ask them to be accountable for the schemes they design, advise and market. With this so-called CCCTB reform, all arrangements that meet even one possible criterion of aggressive tax optimization will have to be reported to the tax authorities, under penalty of penalties. It is also a victory over the smuggling competition — tax competition — which the Member States sometimes indulge in. All information collected will be obligatory and automatically exchanged between the Member States of the European Union. Any progress in this area is good to take, because as we know, States are engaging in a distressing tax race and exchange useful information only if they are forced and forced to do so. Well forced, here they will be, and that's so much the better. Finally, it is a small victory for the European Parliament, more specifically, because through the unanimous vote of the Committee on Economic Affairs, which has substantially improved the text, we prove that our institution is one of the most cutting-edge institutions on the issue of tax evasion. You are going to tell me that this is normal, since we are perhaps the institution that most takes into account the sovereign, the people, the public opinion. On this subject, European society is tired of tax inequalities and is also legitimately revulsed by all these scandals to which I referred. People are watching closely what is happening in Brussels on this issue and that is why we are and we must always be in tune with popular expectations in this area. Finally, it is a technically solid victory, since the CCCTB directive, as it is being voted on today, is considerably enriched, and I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and elected representatives who participated in this work. First of all, we have an obligation to notify the tax authorities of questionable tax arrangements, which will concern not only tax advisors but also auditors. For me, this is very important, because it includes large firms systematically involved in tax scandals and referred to as “Big Four”. You also have the profit leakage that sometimes continues through old assemblies that are always functional, and we ask that all montages, even created several years ago, be notified as soon as they are still in force. Finally, and this is very important, we have expanded the indexes of aggressive tax optimization so that the radar — somehow, if I dare say so — is as complete as possible. So we move forward, we make proposals, we are working with the Commission. Much remains to be done, but it is a small victory, it is a step in the right direction, which must be greeted. Once again, I thank the elected officials who have dealt with this issue, and in particular the shadow rapporteurs, and I invite you to vote massively — if not unanimously — this text, which is going in the right direction.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (NL) Thank you, Mr President. Good morning, colleagues. Leaks like the Panama and the Paradise papers keep the public outrage burning. And that is necessary, because with public pressure, we can bring about political action. I think this directive is a really good example of that. Especially the Paradise papers have shown the importance of intermediaries in tax evasion. It is those specialists who sell the most optimal tax backgates to their customers, as it were. Every individual and every company has, in principle, the right to use these tax backgates, but the core of the problem lies in the fact that not every individual, not every company, has the means to do so. An SME in West Flanders simply cannot afford the services of such a specialist consultant. This goes beyond competition, this is just unfair. This report is therefore very balanced and I think that is important. A good example of this is the obligation to notify new and old constructions with a possible odour. But at the same time, it shouldn't be a manhunt. The exception to leave old constructions that are no longer actively used outside this reporting obligation is therefore justifiable. In this Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, a while ago we made a clear choice in favour of greater fiscal justice and greater transparency. This report fits perfectly into that.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, although it is strange to hold a debate in plenary without the Council and without the Commission, allow me to congratulate the rapporteur as he has brought absolutely significant progress to this proposal for legislation, and all the repeating scandals we have we know how often tax evasion involves complex cross-border arrangements. These only exist because intermediaries, those we are interested in today, whether they are lawyers, accountants, bankers, tax advisors or wealth managers, imagine them and sell them to multinationals, those who have the means to afford such a variety of services. Is it normal for whistleblowers to face justice because they reveal fraud, while those who conceive them would be protected? By obliging the competent national authorities to declare, under penalty of sanctions, the cross-border tax regimes put in place for their customers, this text dissuade the implementation of such dubious mechanisms which reflect a desire to circumvent the law or to unduly reduce the amount of taxes owed. The national authorities will also have to exchange the information collected with each other, thus facilitating cooperation between Member States within a common European legislative framework. It is now up to them to assume their responsibilities, and it seems to us that this deserves to be welcomed as an important step in the implementation of real tax fairness within the European Union. We are, of course, waiting for the Member States at the turn. (She agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — My question goes in the direction: we have now heard from the banks and also from consumers that a lot of new bureaucracy has now moved in. There are massive complaints that bureaucracy in this area has increased dramatically, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises engaged in cross-border business. Are there any proposals here to stop bureaucracy and use automated systems?

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D)
text: answer 'blue card'. — I believe that Mr Rübig has used a 'blue cardboard' to make a plea in favour of SMEs, which is irrelevant to the purpose of this proposal, except by facilitating the denunciation and removing the role of intermediaries which favours the large multinationals, a contrario, of course, this will restore conditions for healthier and more favourable competition for SMEs.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Welcome to Commissioner Moscovici. I wanted to inform you that we are at the following stage: there was a speech by the rapporteur, there were two political groups (PPE and S&D). At that point, I wanted to ask you to come forward.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. — (FR) Mr President, I am sorry for this delay, totally beyond my control, but I had to take a train this morning and the snow had delayed it a bit, which deprived me of the pleasure of hearing previous speakers. In particular, I would like to welcome the rapporteur, Mr Maurel, for his report, which I find very high quality. I will return in a few moments to the proposals contained therein. I am delighted to be able to present before you one of our Commission's flagship proposals on tax transparency as you are preparing to vote this afternoon on a proposal on intermediaries. Recent scandals — the Panama Papers, the Paradise Papers — have shown that banks, accountants, tax advisors, lawyers — some lawyers — played a key role in favouring certain multinationals and organizing arrangements that allow wealthy individuals to escape tax. Faced with this phenomenon, we need more transparency, with a simple idea that is to strengthen the capacity of Member States to prevent and detect this aggressive tax planning that deprives governments and citizens of legitimate resources. That is why last June the Commission adopted a proposal to shed greater light on the practices of these intermediaries. In a nutshell, it is a matter of forcing advisers to inform tax authorities of certain — not all — cross-border schemes that they sell to their clients that can help them evade tax. I want to begin by summarizing, in a few questions, the proposal I had the honour of presenting last June. Question 1: Why would these reporting requirements for intermediaries help reduce tax evasion? The proposal gives Member States more information on the tax planning that could facilitate tax evasion and evasion. The national tax authorities, if the proposal is adopted — which I hope — will then be able to respond more quickly to the risk of abusive tax practices. It will also provide a deterrent effect for those who favor aggressive tax planning mechanisms, since tax authorities will be in a much better position to challenge such planning with early warning systems. Who are the intermediaries we're talking about? These include bankers, lawyers, financial consultants, tax advisors, accountants, etc. including — as seen in a number of spectacular cases — sports agents. Obviously, I want to say this because I do not want to suggest that this proposal is stigmatizing professions that are useful to the common good and that help to the functioning of justice, not everyone in this sector is associated with aggressive tax planning and not any tax arrangement is a tax planning package aggressive. What types of devices should intermediaries communicate to the administration? They will be accountable for any cross-border arrangement that contains one or more of the markers identified in the proposal by the English hallmarks. These markers are elements or features of the transaction that could allow tax evasion. For example, the use of special modalities that involve favourable tax regimes in countries that do not meet the standards of good international governance. Who is required to report these arrangements to the tax authorities? Intermediaries will have a primary obligation to report these plans, but this obligation may be transferred to the taxpayer in certain circumstances. For example, when the intermediary is protected by confidentiality or professional secrecy, where the intermediary is established in a third country or where there is no intermediary because the scheme was designed in some way “in house”. Member States will automatically exchange the information they receive using a central directory managed by the Commission, fully accessible to all Member States. The report you are discussing contains views and ideas that I share. For example, the Commission acknowledges that the lack of reaction by the tax authorities on declared devices should not mean that they cannot be challenged in the future. We also agree that tax administrations and financial intelligence units on money laundering and terrorist financing need to be better coordinated. The rapporteur is right to point out that. However, on your proposal to give the Commission full access to the central directory — although I can of course understand it and appreciate it — I think it should be admitted that we know that the Member States will not accept it. We are not a tax authority, we do not have the same standards of tax secrecy, so if I have sympathy for the proposal as such, I think it implies a number of upstream institutional reforms that we do not have at present. Nor do I think we should harmonize the role of accountants more closely or provide for the publication of sanctions imposed on jurisdictions, intermediaries and taxpayers who do not comply with their obligations. Of course, this does not change the fact that if an intermediary fails to provide the information requested, then national sanctions will apply. The proposal requires Member States to ensure that these penalties are sufficiently severe to discourage cases of non-compliance and we will ensure that this is the case. In conclusion, let me stress how much progress has been made in three years in increasing transparency and cooperation between Member States on tax matters. On this issue of intermediaries, I am delighted to note that the subject was put on the agenda of the next Ecofin on 13 March, which is proof that the dossier is moving forward. I urge you, of course, not to relax the pressure — I trust you for this — to continue this work now at the level of the Member States in partnership with the Bulgarian Presidency. On our other proposals, Member States have agreed to automatically exchange information on financial accounts, cross-border advance tax rulings, country-by-country declarations of multinationals — I continue to believe that these should be made public. They also agreed on new rules that will give tax authorities access to anti-money laundering information, an idea proposed in the wake of the Panama Papers. And of course, I do not forget our April 2016 proposal to make public country-by-country declarations for multinationals to allow citizens and civil society to exercise more control over tax practices. I know that some Member States continue to resist, I regret it, but that is in the direction of history, and I am sure that we will come to an agreement shortly, that is our shared responsibility. I know that the Council, the Commission and Parliament are on the same line and see the need to be ambitious and move things forward. I would like to thank the European Parliament once again for its important contribution to our work and I look forward to, first, the continuation of this debate and, secondly, the vote of your Assembly, which I expect with great confidence.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, thank you to all who are sincerely involved in the important work against tax evasion. Numerous tax scandals, including the LuxLeaks and Panama Papers, raised a stiff on which much work has been done to prevent tax evasion. The latest Paradise Papers data leak showed how work is still badly underway. The motion for a mandatory automatic exchange of information on cross-border tax arrangements, in short DAC6, expands administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. Those planning or promoting cross-border tax arrangements, such as banks and tax advisers, are obliged to report dubious tax arrangements before they are introduced to the tax authorities. The proposal requires information to be submitted to the European Commission and to the Member States' tax authorities. DAC6 is a necessary reform, but one can ask if it is sufficient. So the functionality of the exchange of information needs to be carefully monitored. If this reform is not enough, it is necessary to return to the matter in a quick timescale.

name: Lieve Wierinck
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, many of us talk about fair taxation, but few offer a real solution. Tax avoidance is a problem that has many facets, but the source of this is usually a lack of information. Today we are voting the DAC 6, which is the last proposal in a whole series to combat tax avoidance and should close the last loophole in the net. What makes this proposal so different is that it works preventive. Instead of combating tax avoidance, we are giving Member States the opportunity to anticipate this and secure their revenues for aggressive tax constructions. In addition, it ensures that the information they collect will be automatically shared with each other. This cross-frontier approach will make abuses of different systems between countries a lot more difficult, because it would be naive to think that this problem can be solved entirely at national level. I believe that this proposal will achieve its intended objective.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (GR) Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr President. Maurel for his report. My group will vote in favour of it. It is a positive step and I would like to say that it is one of the reports which seeks to reinforce a positive, albeit late, proposal from the Commission. To combat tax evasion and avoidance, it is never enough that is done. We always need to be more effective because huge sums are being lost, both from public budgets and from the European Union, to the detriment of honest taxpayers, to the detriment of the social state, to the detriment of conquests and to the detriment of the ethics and ethics of the honest people. competition between companies. Those who oppose this proposal actually make it easier for those who evade and deceive tax. We must therefore have stricter framework, sanctions, transparency, cooperation and continually strengthen the arsenal of combating tax fraud which is gaining momentum.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Panama Papers demonstrated the key role played by intermediaries such as banks, accountants and lawyers in helping their clients create offshore structures for tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering, so we welcome this revision to the directive on administrative cooperation, whose aim is to ensure that aggressive tax planning schemes are reported to tax authorities so that they can investigate where necessary. It creates an obligation for intermediaries to disclose potentially aggressive tax planning arrangements, and this information will then automatically be exchanged with other Member States. Parliament has strengthened the Commission’s proposal by requiring an obligation for auditors to report suspect schemes when statutory audits of their clients’ businesses are being carried out and by proposing that the Commission itself should have access to the data exchanged. So we are glad to support this proposal as part of our ongoing work to counter the tax avoidance industry.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, these proposals requiring mandatory exchange of tax information undermine tax sovereignty of the nation states, individual privacy and attorney-client privilege, and also the directors’ duty to arrange the tax affairs of companies in order to pay as little tax as possible. We in Britain believe that the taxpayer has the right to do everything possible within the law – I say within the law – to minimise their tax exposure. You should not have to pay any more tax than is required: not one penny piece. Taxpayers should be allowed to enjoy the fruits of their hard labour, and not have it wasted by the state. The European Union wants to maximise taxation throughout Europe to pay for the fat-cat salaries and the gilded pensions of EU bureaucrats, under increasing bureaucratic tax bunching. This attitude to the rights of the individual is one of the reasons the UK is leaving the EU, and I encourage the Czechs, the Hungarians and the Poles to do likewise. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – It is always a pleasure to address a question to my friend, especially when he is talking about Brexit. Do you know, Mr Coburn, that in the City of London, which is so famous for its banks and the financial companies settled there, lots of European Union directives on taxation have not yet been applied? It seems that the city is already a kind of fiscal paradise. After Brexit it is probably going to become the biggest fiscal paradise in Europe.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I think the City of London will become a fiscal paradise and I think Europeans throughout Europe will be wanting to put their money into Great Britain and into the enterprise that is the City of London, so that they are better off. And, of course, we are the bankers of Europe. Many countries, including Italy, would be in tremendous trouble if they could not borrow money from us. Their banks are in danger of collapse, as is the entire euro system, hence why we are leaving.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Mr President, here we are finding that it is increasingly difficult for Member States to protect their national tax bases against erosion. In parallel, fiscal planning structures are becoming increasingly sophisticated and take advantage of the increased mobility of capital, as well as the lack of greater transparency in the European area. I believe that the fight against aggressive tax planning and structures practicing this kind of activity cannot be carried out as long as they do not in fact violate any legislative provision. I believe that the European institutions are obliged to implement sound and effective legislation across the Union, allowing the protection of the financial interests of the Member States, and secondly, of the Union as a whole. Until these prerequisites are met by strict and transparent legislation, any exchange of information between Member States will not be able to produce concrete results.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, this is once again when the Union fails to live up to the expectations of its citizens. Worse still, not only will this report not address tax evasion by large companies but also raises legitimate concerns about the security of personal data and how these can be used in the future. Firstly, the very tax regime of many Member States allows legal tax avoidance for those who, of course, have the means to identify and exploit the various loopholes in the law. Most importantly, however, the very idea of the single market urges tax avoidance, since not all countries have the same tax regime. Of course, it is absurd to expect a company to remain in one country and pay a multiple tax when it can, by taking advantage of the single market, transfer its registered office and save enormous sums, except, of course, small and medium-sized enterprises which, by their very nature, , unable to do such a thing. However, since uniform taxation would be an unacceptable assignment of national sovereignty for us, we support the return of borders in terms of the movement of goods or the provision of services within the Union.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the effectiveness of tax collection is an indicator of elementary justice. If the state is unable to collect taxes according to the applicable rules, it means that something essential is wrong, and if there are scandals such as Panama papers or Paradise papers, the situation is all the more serious. The fight against tax evasion and fraud must be a self-evident priority in our common European market in its continued integration. I believe that fiscal subsidiarity is of importance and the competence to decide on the level of taxes at national level should be maintained. At the same time, however, there is clearly more to be done to cooperate each country. Mandatory automatic exchange of information on cross-border matters is certainly the right step we need to improve transparency and access to information and thus improve tax collection. This mandatory exchange of information will help, in particular, the Member States themselves, which in many cases lose tax revenues. This is especially true in cross-border cases where national measures cannot even be fully effective. We are also still witnessing cases of outtruded firms in other countries with an effort to conceal the identities of real owners. I believe that mandatory exchange of information is the right way to secure all information for the tax authorities. I believe that the European Parliament's actions will help improve tax collection, make doing business fairer and job creation. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I wonder if you agree with me that all this is in preparation for a pan-European income tax in the future? Do you think the people of your country will be as pleased as the people of all the other European nations to be hit with yet another whopping great tax to pay for the ‘Folies Bergère’ that is the European Parliament?

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card — No, colleague, I do not see it the way you do, and I certainly do not believe that this should be the basis for some common taxation or new taxes. I am a supporter of continuing tax sovereignty, I advocate that taxes should be decided in national countries, but at the same time we need measures to improve the collection of taxes. And through the mandatory exchange of information, I see a good and effective way to improve the collection of taxes.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: Mr President, I believe that this directive is an important directive in the fight against tax evasion. I congratulate the Commission's initiative and congratulate my colleague, Mr Maurel, precisely on the work that this Parliament has done, which I think has made interesting contributions to the initiative, especially as regards the need to have a public record in the Commission on these matters and the need, , to establish penalties for non-compliance with the obligations laid down in this Directive. I would point out, however, that what Parliament is doing is an opinion and that in the fight against tax evasion we are suffering what I would call a retardant and almost boycott of many countries of the Union in the Council. The Council is generally veto, through the need for unanimity, many initiatives in this just fight for tax justice and is setting demands and is providing for opaque tax spaces or European tax havens. This cannot be: that is unsupportive, unsustainable and incompatible with a single market in the European Union.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: — Mr. President, our obligation is to take all measures and protect honest entrepreneurs and taxpayers, protect citizens from those who carry out activities and earn in our countries, but find ways to avoid paying taxes and thereby not only damage the budgets of states but also on dishonest way compete in the market and destroy quality entrepreneurial ventures. We need to prevent the new Panama and Paradise Papers tax scandals. That is why amendments to this Directive are important. Exchange of information about perceived unfair tax practices is key, but more is needed than that. Information is needed that will enable preventive action and the establishment of mechanisms that will deter so-called advisers from designing and placement of arrangements to reduce the tax burden. Better exchange of information, education of tax administrations, exchange of knowledge and experience, involvement of financial institutions and auditors in disclosing information to tax administrations about potential tax avoidance situations are key to creating a system of fairer taxation and markets which will be stimulating for creating new jobs, which is what we want in the European Union — growth and development on quality foundations. Tax evasion certainly doesn't contribute to that.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: - Mr President! Dear ladies! In the House, we have repeatedly criticized adverse tax avoidance practices, with constructing aggressive tax patterns, with so-called tax optimization. These are all practices that, even if they are lawful, Mr Coburn, go against the spirit of the law and most certainly introduce highly harmful discrimination, in particular hurting small and medium-sized businesses. I therefore welcome the Commission's legislative proposal, and therefore I also want to say that I will support the Morel report because these documents are moving towards a revocation of these practices. They will certainly have a chilling effect on the one hand and prevent, in many cases, from proposing by financial intermediaries, banks, tax advisers a variety of dodgy tax schemes. And on the other hand, they provide very important information for the tax authorities, who will be able to seal the tax system and eliminate these adverse practices.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: — Mr President, the schemes of tax evasion and money laundering highlighted by the Panama Papers and Paradise Papers, among other scandals, show how there is a cross-border web of intermediaries, including consultants, bankers, lawyers, accountants and other service providers who are specialized in designing tax evasion and laundering schemes for large multinationals, wealthy clients and mafias to avoid taxes and other legal obligations with opacity and impunity. That is why this Commission proposal which follows Parliament's call in various reports is so important. It aims to ensure the obligation to report cross-border schemes designed by tax intermediaries or taxpayers to the tax authorities of each Member State, including information collected in the automatic exchange of information between tax authorities in the European Union. The excellent report by Emmanuel Maurel, which will be adopted today, aims to strengthen the Commission on the part of Parliament. Let us hope that governments in the Council will not reduce the scope of the obligations to report and share information collected, so that we adopt robust legislation without any subterfuge against transparency and accountability.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, it is a fact that tax evasion and tax avoidance must be struck. We know that and that can be done, first of all, when the obligation is imposed to tax multinationals where they actually make their profits. The second is that the policies of aggressive tax planning are essentially based on the regulations in the Member States themselves and, therefore, by changing the legislation, one can tackle this situation, because only in this way will unfair competition be stopped. It is therefore a positive report and, of course, there must be an exchange of information, but what we need to do is close, by law, the various loopholes which allow tax evasion and avoidance of the various multinationals. So that is where we need to focus mainly, that is the key element: to close all the tricks and all the tax windows.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, direct taxation is not harmonised across the European Union, which means that the freedom of EU citizens and their businesses can enable some taxpayers to avoid or evade tax in their country of residence. The automatic exchange of information on tax rulings should allow the Member States to combat tax evasion, detect companies’ abusive tax practices and consequently take any necessary action against them. I support the Commission proposal to improve and strengthen administrative cooperation between the Member States’ tax administrations, and I consider it important for the Member States to strengthen the financial and human resources of the tax administration. Nevertheless, it is important to have strong and corresponding sanctions, which should be financial as well as granting access to the central depository. This could also strengthen the EU’s competitive policy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: — Madam President, the exchange of information on cross-border arrangements in the context of better, more transparent and fairer taxation and the fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion is extremely important. If we want capital and people mobility and a functioning single market, we need to have clear rules on which entities act on it. In doing so, we must always take care that extra regulation costs and that big economic operators will be much easier to bear that cost than the medium-sized and small companies that form the backbone of the European economy. Therefore, I am once again appealing for a change in tax policies that must be stimulating, while penalties for evasion and evasion should become tougher. In this way, these harmful practices and crimes become unprofitable, so fewer and fewer subjects will try to hide their money from the state at all.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tax planning structures have evolved, becoming particularly sophisticated and often benefiting from increased capital mobility and people in the domestic market. They generally consist of mechanisms that develop between different jurisdictions and transfer taxable profits to favourable tax schemes or have as effect that of reducing taxes payable towards taxpayers. Under these conditions it is increasingly difficult for Member States to protect national tax bases from erosion, which prevents them from enforcing growth-friendly fiscal policies. Amendment to the directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation aimed at strengthening transparency is undoubtedly an important element in the strategy to combat evasion and Commission tax avoidance. However, the main problem of the lack of a fair European tax system, which is a fiscal union, which completely frustrates any attempt at economic cohesion and social in Europe and disproportions the possibilities of escaping and evading the IRS.

name: Pierre Moscovici
