text: Member of the Commission. — (FR) Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Members for this very interesting exchange of views, which, above all, bodes for a good conclusion for this text, and it will be an important signal if this text is voted, as I can feel at the conclusion of this debate, in a largely transpartisan way. We all — or almost all — share the conviction that the time has come for greater transparency on the practices of intermediaries. These have actually worked too long in the shadows. I recently used the bold image — I agree — of vampires to qualify some perpetrators as tax evasion. Yet, even if bold, the formula was not inaccurate: some thrive as long as there is secrecy and thrive only in secrecy. Transparency is therefore the only effective weapon, the main weapon to counter tax evasion and evasion. This is the objective that our proposal on intermediaries is once again pursuing. The tax authorities — I am sure — need this additional source of information, because otherwise they would not be able to identify a particular device during the audit of a company because they do not have an overview. I believe that this new proposal will greatly help the tax authorities improve their effectiveness in combating tax evasion mechanisms. I believe it represents a new step in supporting fairness in the area of taxation. Once adopted, this directive will ensure a level playing field. It will provide greater security to intermediaries who respect the spirit and letter of our legislation and will make life very difficult for those who do not. At present, let's recognize that it may be difficult for some companies that do not practice tax planning to compete with the multinational companies that use aggressive tax regimes to avoid paying their fair share of taxes. It is all the more unfair because it also means that honest taxpayers have to pay more than their fair share to compensate for the shortfall and ensure the financing of the public services and common goods that our fellow citizens need. I have committed myself to this fight until the end of my mandate, and I will do so, because from day one, my goal and that of this Commission is to ensure that all taxpayers, citizens and businesses, are on an equal footing and that no one is undoubtful privileged. I would again like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent work, which, I believe, is a basis for a very broad approval from this House, which will be a strong political signal of will and which I look forward to. Thank you for your attention and for this new proof of support for what the Commission has undertaken since November 2014 — probably at its pace, and this is also the pace of public decision — but with total determination, which we share, and I believe it is for the good of all.

name: Emmanuel Maurel
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for these remarks, which still show almost unanimity in this Chamber, which consists in saying that fiscal inequalities threaten our democratic pact, that there is no equality of citizens without equal tax and that there is no stable and European state stable and respected, which leak tens of billions of euros of public revenue every year. So I have heard the comments of each other and, to quote one colleague, it is obviously not a question of stigmatizing professions, but of trying to deter some of these professionals from engaging in what I called a “tax evasion industry”, in any case tax optimization, which we all denounced this morning. Commissioner Moscovici invited us to be aware of the progress that had been made over the last three years. It is true that the Commission and Parliament are trying to work at their own pace to find answers. It is also true, however — let us be honest, ladies and gentlemen — that the Council is not helping us much and that we will not have to relieve the pressure on Member States which, on this issue, are rarely ahead and rarely want to anticipate a number of debates. Thank you ladies and gentlemen, I hope that this text will be voted with the widest possible majority so that we can send — in the words of the Commissioner — a political signal of the desire to restore equality of citizens and businesses in the face of taxes.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. — Mandatory automatic exchange of tax information for transnational arrangements is the main instrument available to Member States to prevent and identify tax evasion and situations where taxable income is not declared. That is why the European Commission's initiative, in this respect, is welcome. I believe that there is a need, too, in this case, to have a list of tax jurisdictions that do not wish to cooperate in that area and, possibly, to introduce the necessary sanctions. Tax evasion and tax avoidance, through a kind of practice, must be stopped in the general interest of citizens.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I welcome the report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation and congratulate the EP, especially the S&D group, which has been struggling for a long time to restore tax justice in Europe — which has already achieved a number of serious results in this square. Against aggressive tax planning, it is not possible to fight alone, solely in the competence of the Member States. Community, European action is needed to finally close the loopholes so that we can remove the unfair tax burden from the shoulders of honest taxpayers citizens and SMEs. Automatic exchange of information between tax authorities, increased transparency and stricter action against intermediate operators assisting in tax evasion schemes will help in this. At the same time, I would recall that the legislation assumes that it works with independent tax authorities operating in European legal states. And here is the limitation of the law, because in the case of Hungary, unfortunately, this does not exist — neither the rule of law nor the authorities that are independent of the Hungarian government. I am therefore sad to draw attention to the fact that, under these conditions, the EU certainly cannot expect bona fide cooperation from this Member State to avoid aggressive tax planning.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Javier Nart, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on a European Parliament recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on cutting the sources of income for jihadists – targeting the financing of terrorism (2017/2203(INI)) (A8—0035/2018).

name: Javier Nart
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, the defeat of the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq does not mean an end: in your hands there is a huge amount of money that has been stored throughout your caliphate with the sale of oil, the capture or investment of legitimate businesses, revolutionary taxes, robberies, bank assaults, kidnapping, trafficking in antiques, arms sales. Approximately $400 million is estimated to be laundered in Syria and Iraq, considering that the approximate volume of their economic movement, at the time of the caliphate, was about $80 million per month. The purpose of this Recommendation is to collapse, prevent the use of these funds, that they can be laundered, that their loot can be marketed, because intelligence services need to function in a coordinated manner to combat the financing of terrorism. It is therefore proposed to the Commission, the Member States and the European External Action Service a comprehensive, comprehensive vision that will deepen the necessary cooperation between European intelligence services. The creation of a horizontal platform for European intelligence services where they can share data and research is a strategic necessity. It is not a question of creating a new institution but, realistically, of establishing a cooperation platform where there is a joint database and where this data can be shared. And this platform we are proposing must be built on the basis of what already exists in Europol, with a proactive exchange of information on the financing of terrorist groups. Member States are also encouraged to devote more efforts to equip themselves with qualified personnel, IT engineers who are able to properly detect and investigate economically suspicious movements. We also call for the early implementation of the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive to improve the competition of national intelligence units and to have access to bank details, including within the scope of the Directive, for their investigation, virtual currencies and prepaid cards, cards which, until now, were recharged anonymously, and that must be ended. New technologies have a fundamental role and responsibility. Virtual currencies, crowdfundig platforms are used by terrorists. New technologies are, by their very nature, cross-border, such as the response to terrorism, which is also cross-border. We have international agreements on the exchange and traceability of financial information linked to terrorism, but, very curiously, we do not do the same within the European Union. This is the case with the single euro payment area, and we therefore propose to the Commission that it pursue measures that can complement the international system with a joint European response, all strictly applying data protection standards and respect for the fundamental rights that define us as respectful of rights in the European Union. We also propose that, in the European Union, in particular the arrangements for the traditional transfer of money from hawala to Chinese fei ch'ien and other traditional arrangements, be regulated by a register of compulsory transactions, as is the case with any of our fellow citizens, who, when transfer money, do so in a controlled manner: equality before the law and non-discrimination. Hawala is being used by the Islamic State, by terrorist organizations to export their money from Syria and Iraq, and that money comes to Europe. Similarly, in Europe we must pay our attention to centres of worship, cultural and charitable associations — apparent charitable associations — where there is reason to suspect that have links to terrorism, in order to avoid negligent or reckless use of the funds they receive, all with particular attention to the fight against this new form of racism and xenophobia, which is Islamophobia. Terrorism defined as jihadism is blasphemy against the Qur'an and the main victims of this terrorist activity are precisely Muslims. Finally, in our external dimension, in the missions we send and finance from our common security and defence policy, as part of the assistance we provide to building resilience in the States victims of terrorist crime, we must add the dimension of the fight against the financing of terrorism and, especially against the integration into the own economy of funds captured by terrorists, that is, money-laundering through lawful economic activities. In conclusion, I would like to thank the colleagues with whom I negotiated the text, and also Commissioner King, with whom I had the opportunity to exchange views on the proposal for a Recommendation. I have sought the Recommendation to be realistic and possible and effective. And I am grateful that my efforts to combine the necessary and difficult balance between freedom and security have obtained the consensus of all political groups. Thanks to all of them.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, terrorists need to raise and move funds to maintain their networks, cover their logistical needs and commit their attacks. We need to close down the space in which they can do this. Countering terrorist financing is not only about limiting their capacity to act, but also about, as we have just heard, using financial intelligence to detect and stop terrorists before they act. Recent attacks perpetrated in Europe have been financed with relatively small sums of money, and that poses some new challenges to those who are working on the front line to prevent terrorist attacks. We need to give law enforcement and our public authorities the tools they need to do their job and to help keep us safe. So I very much welcome the timely recommendations in this report. Tackling terrorist financing is a high priority for all of us. From the Commission side, it is a key part of our work to build an effective security union. Our approach was set out in the Action Plan for strengthening the fight against terrorist financing of February 2016, and we are now taking that work forward on two fronts: detecting and preventing terrorist funding, and disrupting the sources of revenue. That covers a range of different measures: preventing the misuse of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing; increasing cooperation and the exchange of information between competent authorities, in particular financial intelligence units; tracing the financial movements of terrorists; improving the effectiveness of asset-freezing systems; reinforcing the judicial response to terrorist financing and money laundering; supporting third countries in countering terrorist financing and money laundering in their implementation of the Financial Action Task Force standards; supporting customs authorities with tools to identify sources of revenue of terrorist organisations; and supporting third countries as they engage with international partners, not only through the FATF, as I mentioned, but also other bodies such as the Anti-ISIS Coalition working group on countering financing of terrorism, and indeed the work that is done in the framework of the G-7. So I am glad to see that many of the report’s recommendations are in line with the work that we are undertaking. We welcome the emphasis in the report on information-sharing, in particular among financial intelligence units, as well as other national agencies. We welcome your support for the establishment of central bank account registries. I am glad to say, as announced in the Commission work programme for this year, we will soon present initiatives to improve cross-border access to financial data for law enforcement authorities. This will include measures to facilitate access to national centralised bank account registries and retrieval systems within Member States. We will also propose measures to improve the cooperation between law enforcement authorities and the various financial intelligence units. In line with the report’s recommendations, we have reinforced Europol’s role in this fight against terrorist financing. We take note of the call for increasing monitoring of prepaid cards. The Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive is a step forward, I think, in reinforcing the transparency around this means of payment. With its list of non-cooperative jurisdictions, the EU is also acting to increase the exchange of information on tax matters with third countries, as you have been discussing. This will help national administrations to detect the presence of illicit money and money-laundering. We appreciate your support for the EU-US Terrorist Finance Tracking Programme and we take note of your call for a European system to complement that. On asset-freezing, we appreciate the report’s support for existing measures. The EU’s asset-freezing efforts have been reinforced with the autonomous EU regime against al-Qaeda and Daesh. We appreciate the emphasis on hawala. In the supranational risk assessment of money laundering and terrorism financing risks, the Commission recommended that hawala service providers should apply the requirements related to money-transfer systems under the payment services directive and the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, and we are committed to keeping this particular sector under close review. In relation to high-value goods, I would like to underline that the proposal to amend the Cash Control Regulation expands the definition of cash to gold and other high-value commodities. We appreciate your support for our proposed regulation on the import of cultural goods. This issue remains of high importance in addressing the problem of cultural goods being illegally taken from third countries, from their proper historical and archeological context, and being brought to the EU. This can in turn foster organised crime, terrorist financing, money laundering and tax evasion. Member States should also soon adopt the Commission’s proposals to strengthen the VAT system and reinforce the collective fight against VAT fraud, which again can feed criminal and terrorist organisations. So in a nutshell, I am glad that the work the Commission is doing in this area is in line with many of the measures you call for and support in today’s report. Some other new measures you suggest merit further analysis. We will take a careful look at them and we will come back to you on them.  Countering financing of terrorism is a core component of the EU strategy in the fight against terrorism and hence in our work to build an effective security union. As the terrorists and their supporters constantly modify and change the ways they collect, move and get access to funds, we need to be ready to adopt and adapt our response. The EU needs to adapt its instruments and measures to deprive terrorists of the space and the means they use as they seek to do us harm. I count on your continued support as we take this work forward.

name: Lars Adaktusson
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate my colleague, Javier Nart, for a well drafted report. Despite the defeat of ISIS, we are not in a position to declare victory over terrorism. Instead, we should learn from both the rise and fall of Islamic State. One lesson is that the combination of military means and cutting off the financial lifeblood of ISIS has paved the way for its departure.  Another lesson is that, after the dismantling of an organisation like ISIS, there will be a vacuum. Certain actors will do their utmost to fill that space with new Jihadist organisations, and for that they will need money. Cutting the funding sources of terrorist networks should therefore be considered a key priority. It constitutes an effective tool, hampering the effectiveness of these networks. To achieve this, implementation is crucial: the Member States, for instance, should deliver when it comes to the exchange of intelligence. With common efforts, the EU is able to cope with the bloodstream of Jihadism: the capital flow that today finances international terrorism.

name: Clare Moody
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur and my fellow shadow rapporteurs for the constructive way in which we have worked together. I believe this has led to a good report with realistic recommendations. The changes we suggested in this report can be embraced by law-enforcement bodies across Europe, for example by creating a platform where data can be shared. The small amounts of money that are needed for terrorists to carry out their criminal acts in our cities mean that we need to be better at monitoring even small transactions, including traditional forms of exchange, such as hawala. We also need to recognise that Daesh move money into legitimate businesses but in countries with weak institutions, which is why we need to support institution-building in fragile states. This report also stresses that, while we must deal with terrorist financing, it is ultimately through tackling the root causes of poverty, social exclusion and human rights abuses that we will defeat the destructive ideology that breeds terrorism. I have mentioned just a few of the examples of the practical solutions that are outlined in this report. Our citizens rightly expect us to keep them safe, and that is why I believe this report is important. It is a demonstration of the practical ways that the EU works for the people across Europe.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, it goes without saying that tackling and tracking terrorists’ financial resources is one of the key tools in our fight against global terrorism. I too welcome many of the recommendations in the Nart report and strongly support the overall endorsement of greater cooperation amongst the EU Member States in this area. It’s clear that terrorism and its financing know no borders and this can only be tackled at the multilateral level. In the UK there is some evidence that ISIS may well have sold some of its antiquities smuggled out. As the UK leaves the EU, external and internal security will be one of the key areas where it is vital, no matter what else transpires for Britain, to stay plugged in. So I welcome the Prime Minister, Ms May’s positive comments in this regard during her Munich security conference speech and I hope that accommodation can be found to avoid a security cliff edge if no deal were to transpire during phase two of the negotiations. Finding ways to ensure data protection regulation alignment between the UK and the EU post-Brexit will also be one of the keys to unlocking coordination in the long term between the EU 27 and a post-Brexit Britain.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, first of all I would really like to thank my colleague Javier Nart for his excellent work and the very relevant initiative. Gracias Javier. Colleagues, of course, the citizens are asking us to take action against terrorists, and so we must also ensure that we drain the financing of the terrorists. That is why I believe that the recommendations we are sending from Parliament today to the Commission and the Commissioner to really dry out these financial flows are very important. They are very concrete, Commissioner. You have listed them: more control over the big and, as the others say, the small transactions. More controls on those prepaid cards. See what gifts go abroad. What happens to the money flows to the mosques? We don't have to be silly. Terrorists need funding if they want to commit terrorist attacks. That is why I am also very pleased with the intelligence platform on finance that we are asking to set up today. However, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to go one step further today. Since 2014, 17 attacks have happened in Europe and if you just look at the perpetrators, one or more perpetrators of most attacks were in one or more databases. That is why I would like to use this moment today to make another statement. We need to move on. We need to go to a real European intelligence service.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Nart for having managed to present a comprehensive and balanced report. Ladies and gentlemen, nineteen years since the first United Nations resolution on this issue, more terrorist organisations are now operating with more money than ever before. This reality will not change as long as we insist, unequivocally, on preventing the financing of terrorists through the international financial system. After all, it is this system that develops and adopts some of the instruments used by terrorists to finance them. Moreover, most attacks in Europe today require very little resources and terrorists use methods of transferring and raising funds that avoid the international financial system. It is hypocritical to pretend to try to combat terrorism when working with countries that deliberately allow it to be hatched. Commissioner, tell us which states and regimes the European Union cooperates with, even though they are directly or indirectly involved in the financing of terrorist organisations? Tell us who's arming them? Tell us what you are doing to help regions where terrorist organisations are developing to cope with the illegal economic structures that feed them? When did you actually work to promote development in these areas? When did you work to improve governance and combat corruption in these areas? That is what your policy should focus on in the fight against terrorism, if you really believe that you can and want to defeat it.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — I really congratulate and welcome the work prepared by the rapporteur, which I think is particularly important in the context of today. I also want to draw attention to the two cornerstones that we need to address. This is, above all, transparency in banking activities. Although the banking system is considered too important to undertake radical reforms, transparency and, above all, effective measures to destroy tax havens would make it difficult to finance terrorism and contribute to the competitiveness of the European economy as a whole. Second — ideological. The vast majority of terrorist groups operate on a religious basis. Maybe it is time to think that Europe should take real action to encourage the emergence of democratic religious movements as a kind of analogue of the Christian Democratic Party. This would become a viable alternative to religious extremism and would enable representatives of currently marginalised denominations to express themselves in democratic political life.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, despite the myriad rules and regulations introduced into the banking system, I strongly believe that the only way to stop the flow of funds to jihadists is to physically deny them their safe havens. We know sympathisers raise funds across the globe and extort money through kidnapping and other crimes to support these wicked people. However, the greatest funding comes from control of a territory, especially territory such as we’ve seen in Iraq, with natural resources such as oil and gas. It is imperative that we prevent jihadists from controlling such areas and incumbent on nation states – not the European Union – to protect their citizens by empowering their military forces to take whatever necessary action.

name: Dominique Martin
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, Madrid, London and Paris, we have been waiting for this report for more than a decade. Should we recall that the terrorist attacks in Europe have been 2,400 dead since 2001? 2,400 dead since 2001! That ISIS's annual revenue would amount to $3 billion? $3 billion! Of course, we must ensure that we do not participate in this financing, particularly through the purchase of oil. But what do you offer us? What do you offer us? To entrust our security to the European institutions and banking institutions. Out of 100 dollars laundered worldwide, banks only intercept 80 cents — the price of a baguette — demonstrating their helplessness. As for the European institutions, they argue — and I quote Mrs Mogherini, High Representative of the European Union for Security Policy — that 'political Islam has a place in Europe'. Political Islam has its place in Europe. Do you really want to entrust them with our security?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: — Madam President, ISIS may have been militarily defeated on all fronts, but if the terrorist activity of the jihadists is to be effectively combated, or at least reduced, the possibility of financing them. This is a difficult task, because terrorists are constantly changing their funding methods. At the moment, we know that the financing of terrorists is mainly through banks of Western and Arab countries, which openly support them, as well as through donations of supporters with small sums, which come from the profits of small businesses, thus circumventing the financial system. That is why all the authorities and security services in all countries need to cooperate so that information can be exchanged. The accounts of suspected depositors must also be audited at banks. But this does not allow the rights of depositors to be violated. Nor should it be used to prosecute political opponents.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: — Madam President, this report by Javier Nart is very important. The Daexe did not end, even if territorially defeated. No more heads of the terrorist network, from Al Qaeda to Boko Haram. The fight against terrorism must be at the heart of the European Union's security agenda, particularly with regard to the MENA region, without allowing it to be exploited by political, geopolitical and sectarian ambitions of regional states. A priority in this context is the monitoring and blocking of funding for terrorist networks via systems such as wallets and cryptocurrencies, but also investing in legal business, particularly in Iraq, Turkey, but also in the European Union itself. Commissioner Moscovici himself, in a report on 'caroel fraud on VAT, a year ago, showed that EUR 50 billion a year is diverted and recycled by terrorist organisations, including terrorist groups such as Al Qaeda. Our Member States continue to refuse the reforms that have been proposed in the VAT system to remedy this. The fourth anti-money laundering directive is not yet being implemented by several Member States and Member States have refused, under the fifth directive, to set up a European financial research unit, which is absolutely indispensable to combat terrorist financing.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: Madam President! It is welcome that, with the report we are discussing today, and with the establishment of a committee looking at counter-terrorism, the European Parliament is starting to take seriously the threat and fight against terror. For too many years, the European Parliament has been a stopgap for effective anti-terrorism legislation. We can just look at the whole process around getting European PNR rules adopted. That is why I also welcome this report and the rapporteur's work. However, I am sorry that in the vote in the AFET we voted down a number of ECR proposals that could have made the report even more robust and even more effective in preventing terrorist financing. In particular, the state sponsoring of terrorism, which we see from certain countries in the Middle East, has unfortunately not been given the role in the report that we in the ECR Group had liked to see. That is why I hope that we can tackle the challenges that state-sponsored terrorism causes more effectively in the context of our recommendations from the Committee on Terrorism.

name: André Elissen (ENF).
text: Mr President, in recent years Europe has been startled by numerous Islam-inspired and legitimised terrorist attacks. According to the EU Counter-Terrorism Coordinator, there are more than 50 000 radicalised Muslims in Europe. Yet the word Islam comes back exactly zero times in the report, zero times. What this Parliament is doing is nothing more than a drop on a glowing record. The title of that report is good. The content is completely inadequate. There is talk of nonsensical terms such as Islamophobia and so-called attacks on Muslims. This is while Islamists are responsible for 99% of all terrorist murders in 2015 and 95% of all terrorist killings in 2016. Mr President, these are not my data, but Europol's data. Critics are given a stamp to be Islamophobic, while the real cause, Islam, is not appointed. It's the reverse world. Mr President, as far as we are concerned, there is no place in Europe for jihadists and radicalised Muslims, and the borders are immediately closed.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: Madam President! In the centre of Copenhagen there are large concrete blocks everywhere, and in most other European big cities you see the same view. They do not embellish in the cityscape, but they are there for a reason: to protect us from terror, to stop those who will us it evil! Just as we set physical stopblocks for terrorism in our cities, we must also set regulatory stop blocks for those who fund terror. Unfortunately, there are far too many banks which put profits above principles. They do not keep track of who is transferring money to whom and which pockets the money falls into, and also the fact that European banks are unwittingly helping to finance terror and terrorist organisations via whitewash, sizzle and fraud. Whitewash nourishes and enables terror, and both are best nurtured in darkness. That is why it is high time we cracked down hard on those money laundering banks which do not take their responsibilities seriously. Thank you for a good report and the important decision we will take in this House.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: — Dear Madam President, honourable Members, in recent years we have discussed and commented on the threat to the security of European citizens, which gives rise to the connection of Islamist organisations, extreme radical Islamism, with terrorist groups on European territory. In recent years, we have commented on, discussed and addressed the issue of funding ISIS, DAESS, al-Qaeda, al-Nusra and other similar threats to our way of life. In the course of the war, these terrorist organizations lost over 90% of their territories and many of their fighters to the bloody campaigns for Raqqa and Mosul. This forced ISIS to return to its cellular structure, shaped and developed between 2009 and 2011. We should not take this as a victory, but rather as a small step towards the debacle of jihadism. I must point out that because of territorial losses and oil trade, ISIS is already reorienting itself towards the distribution of drugs and arms. These goods come mainly through channels from Africa and Asia. We should note the funding of jihadist groups from the Republic of Turkey, Saudi Arabia and other Gulf countries. We must set firm conditions for the termination of this funding, because it is a direct threat to national security for all countries and Members of the European Parliament.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to congratulate Mr Nart on this report, which is directly at the centre of our citizens' concerns and which, if he has a merit, is to present a catalogue of concrete proposals: for example, the stable platform for cooperation of financial intelligence services within the framework of Europol means the catalogue of undertakings, banks or financial institutions which have deficiencies with regard to money-laundering or cooperation with third countries through political dialogue, financial assistance and strengthening their counter-terrorism capacity. I think we must congratulate ourselves on this cooperation between the FATF and the Gulf Cooperation Council. It seems to me that this report, Madam President, also clearly reveals a number of duties to the Commission to make the appropriate proposals, to the Council for the effective implementation of sanctions, to the Member States and the External Action Service, to be able, as the Commissioner said, to be able to respond adequately to this scourge which threatens our societies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: –Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, from 2014 to 2017 – in four years – we have seen 45 big terrorist attacks in Europe that caused hundreds of victims. This situation cannot continue, Commissioner. The security of EU citizens has to become the first priority of the European Union’s specialised institutions. I believe that law enforcement and prevention strategy are important, both among EU Member States and in the European Union’s external relations. The fight against Daesh and Al-Qaeda should remain at the top of the security agenda in Europe, but of course in the Middle East as well, and not be diverted, especially in the Middle East, to pursuing particular political and sectarian agendas of the regional actors. I strongly believe that, in our fight against terrorists, we need to focus our efforts on police and judicial cooperation and on exchanging information and data and good practices so as to strengthen synergies in the global … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the reduction in the sources of income of the jihadists will of course take place when funding, their own and, of course, the financing of terrorism, are targeted. In order to do this, we must of course control the countries which have supported the jihadists and we know which ones they are. It's Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Turkey. Turkey smuggled fuel in support of the jihadists themselves. So that's where we need to turn. We need to find ways to freeze the assets of those who really work in favour of the jihadists, in Turkey and in other countries. These are very specific measures that we need to take. In addition, we also need to control the huge sums of money laundering in football. Many Arab countries support football teams, aimed at further radicalising the poor Muslim populations. All of this must be seen in order to be able to deal with the jihadists.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Madam President, on the extremely important problem of terrorism, and especially on the problem of Islamic terrorism, we have been vertical and clear from the outset. No tolerance for terrorists, but no tolerance for those who support or finance their actions. Unfortunately, no serious step has been taken so far in the semi-official state funding of terrorist organisations. A typical example is the case of Turkey, for which it is now a common secret that for a long time it has financed the Islamic Caliphate through oil smuggling. Also, everyone in this Chamber is aware of the mildly controversial role played by Saudi Arabia, Qatar and other Gulf states and the sometimes overt support they provide for the various Islamist organisations that act as communicating vessels with terrorists. The war in Syria in particular has been extremely revealing as to the role of these states. It is therefore necessary to check the suspicious funding which is often covered in the cloak of charities. When and where such transactions are found, very severe sanctions should be imposed - not only on persons but also on the Member States themselves.

name: Arndt Kohn (S&D).
text: Madam President! Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Foreign Affairs warmly for its own-initiative report on combating terrorist financing. The report is an important impetus for Parliament to move forward at last with the regulation on imports of cultural goods. Last week, the results of the Athena and Pandora 2 operations were announced by Interpol and the World Customs Organization, which confiscated 41,000 illegally traded art objects, including many ancient ones. The trade in art and cultural goods is now as pronounced as the drug or arms trade; the UN identified the link with terrorist financing back in 2015. We must not allow such a business model to work due to the lack of customs regulations and to fund attacks in Europe and elsewhere. I call on Parliament and all Member States to work for better customs controls, better training of customs officials and effective international cooperation. Because only together can we combat illicit trafficking in cultural goods and prevent attacks... (The President has taken the speaker out of the speaker).

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: — Madam President, the abolition of sources of income for jihadist organizations is the basis of effective fight against terrorism. I support all mechanisms by which we will effectively combat terrorist financing, including better surveillance of religious institutions for which there are indications that they are involved in the spread of extremism, but these mechanisms must be selective enough not to engage innocent citizens and negatively affect their freedom. We must not forget that financial and logistical assistance to terrorists, directly or indirectly, often comes from ourselves. Our hypocritical foreign policy refusing to make clear towards some countries that are proven sponsors of international terrorism and the recognition and arming of groups that are not true partners to us also contribute to strengthening jihadists. For our own good, we need to be much more consistent and cautious, which means that we finally have to have the right strategy rather than be guided by day-political motives. (The speaker agreed to answer the question raised by raising the blue card (Article 162, paragraph 8. Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question under the 'blue card' procedure. — Madam President, honourable colleague, in principle I agree with what you said. But you said, among other things, that we were to blame, that we did not take sufficient measures. Can you tell us what Parliament, the European Union, the Commission should do to end the financing of terrorism and acts of terrorism? Because it is good to criticize, but also to come up with solutions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. — Colleagues, you know very well that some Member States are still trading with those who are said not to trade. So one thing we're talking about here, the other we do. If laws are passed that we all have to work together to combat corruption, then we all have to work together, not that some states can and some cannot. Therefore, according to everyone should be the same laws.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to express particular thanks to Mr Nart for the report and thank everyone for today’s important debate. I want to caution against the suggestion that in some way we have a defeated Daesh. We have made very welcome progress on the ground against the so-called caliphate, but Jihadi extremist terrorism remains active in a number of countries and the terrorist threat – including to us here in Europe – remains very high. They are still able to produce and spread poisonous propaganda. We will be announcing some new measures to tackle that aspect of the problem later today. They still have access to significant sources of funding and funds that they have previously raised. That is why the work that you’ve been highlighting in this report to disrupt the sources of revenue of terrorist organisations, to limit their capacity to move and use funds and to support law enforcement in their efforts to detect financial movements of terrorists, in order to identify them and frustrate their plans and tackle the networks, is so important. I agree with those who’ve underlined the importance of making progress on information exchange and information-sharing. We have made some progress, there is still more that needs to be done. With the help and support of this House, I hope that this year we will be able to agree to further strengthen the key law-enforcement and information-sharing networks and databases and make sure that they work together effectively. In particular, we’re going to come forward with further proposals to strengthen the network of financial intelligence units and the ability of law enforcement to work with those units, and I hope you will support that. I agree with those who’ve spoken about the transnational character of the terrorist threat, and that is why we need a common European approach. That approach needs to be rooted in and complementary with actions taken at national level and international cooperation. That’s our objective. That’s the work that we’re pursuing, with your help and support, to continue to build an effective security union to better protect our citizens.

name: Javier Nart
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, an issue as extraordinarily sensitive as it is important: more than two hundred and eighty amendments, a complete consensus, satisfied groups, Commissioner King happy and me too.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: in writing. — (NL) The approach and prevention of terrorist financing are crucial in the fight against terrorism. Once the resources dry up, it becomes a lot more difficult for terrorists to carry out their activities. That is why we need to get a better understanding of these flows as soon as possible, and intercept and punish shadowy transactions. However, this will only be possible if cooperation at European level is also optimal. Specifically, the creation of a European terrorist financing intelligence platform should further improve the exchange of information between national intelligence services. Parliament also called for a European financial tracing system to be put in place so that payment transactions to and from terrorist networks can be traced efficiently. The new anti-money laundering directive on which the EU reached agreement at the end of last year is already an important step forward in the fight against terrorist financing. For example, intelligence services should have easier access to bank registers in case of legitimate suspicions of terrorist connections. But intelligence agencies must also exchange that information between themselves efficiently. Belgium already plays a leading role in this area, including the ban on anonymous prepaid cards. Let us also share such good practices with other Member States in order to develop an effective and proactive European approach.

name: Monika Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing — The effective fight against terrorism and the prevention of related threats requires targeted measures aimed at stopping the various forms of financing it. Snipping terrorist networks away from money resources is crucial in terms of enhancing security. An essential part of these efforts is the further development of cooperation between the Member States of the European Union. The aim is not to create new institutions or bodies at European level, but to strengthen coordination within existing information exchange systems. Terrorism is a threat to the freedom of European countries and their people. The effective fight against organised groups, as well as individuals that threaten the safety of citizens, is therefore a top priority. We must not allow the system of rights and certainty, which is an important part of the European integration project, to continue to be jeopardised. The main goal of all extremists and radicals indiscriminately is the spread of confusion, an increase in fear and chaos in society. Any measures taken must therefore be comprehensive and rational, including because they always represent a certain degree of burden on public budgets.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. — Mr President, the world and Europe have been grappling with terrorism on an Islamist basis for many years. One of the main elements of the fight against terrorism is the cutting off of sources of funding, including through secret chains of fraud and tax evasion, money laundering and tax havens. Funding of legal origin may unfortunately be directed by the beneficiary to third parties, individuals, groups, companies or entities involved in terrorist activities. It is worth noting that terrorism is a global crime, so an effective response must also be global and inclusive, with international coordination between financial institutions, law enforcement authorities and judicial authorities and the exchange of relevant information on natural and legal persons and suspicious activities are essential, given that the protection of personal data and the protection of privacy are important fundamental rights. It is therefore worth supporting the record contained in the report calling on the EU Council to tighten up targeted sanctions and other restrictive measures for all individuals and entities who provide economic resources in any way to ISIS/ Da'esh, Al-Qaida or other jihadist groups.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Written. — I support the Parliament's proposal as preventive strategies based on the exchange of best practices and the exchange of suspicious relevant information between intelligence services are essential in combating terrorist financing or terrorist attacks. Disabling sources of financing for terrorist networks should be a priority, as it is an effective tool to reduce the performance of these networks. The establishment of a network of counter-terrorism experts in EU delegations, providing funding for programmes aimed at promoting the exchange of best practices between intelligence services within EU Member States as well as third countries, are urgently needed measures. The call for Member States to create joint investigation units with Europol to monitor suspicious organisations engaged in activities such as illegal trade, smuggling, counterfeiting and fraudulent practices is very positive. We urgently need programmes and resources from Member States to enable these programmes to be successful.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I would like first to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Nart, on a very good report with a catalogue of specific solutions. Combating the financing of terrorism is a demanding topic and I agree that it should be a key priority, as it constitutes a useful tool in hampering the effectiveness of terrorist networks. All Member States should make every effort, and should take joint action, to cut the flow of funds and other financial assets and economic resources to individuals and entities on the ISIL (Daesh) and al-Qaeda sanctions list. We repeatedly underline how extremely important it is that information sharing among financial intelligence units should be improved and speeded up. Therefore, it is a crucial aspect of the sharing of best practices among intelligence agencies. The report rightly pointed to the investigation and analysis of terrorists and of terrorist organisations’ methods of recruiting and the transfer of terrorist financing. There is no doubt that, as the EU, we must continue to oppose cruel and unacceptable acts of terrorism. We should remember that the fight against terrorism is fundamental to the security of European society. We are required to take appropriate measures in response to every type of threat against our citizens.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Izaskun Bilbao Barandica and Ángela Vallina, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the EU priorities for the 62nd session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women (2017/2194(INI)) (A8—0022/2018).

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, I should like to begin this speech by thanking Ángela Vallina in particular for her spirit, ideas and enthusiasm for working together on a report which also thanks and welcomes the contributions of all those who have worked with us. I believe that for the first time in the history of mankind there is a generalized powerful movement for equality that we want to help make progress with work like the one we are presenting today. The text we are discussing today will be the Union's contribution this year to the main intergovernmental forum dedicated to promoting women's equality and empowerment: the UN Commission on the Status of Women. The Community institutions must ensure the full participation of Parliament and its Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality in their 62nd Assembly, which this year is dedicated to improving the situation of rural women and to pay particular attention to their access to new technologies and the media. The Union wants to play a leading role in promoting and strengthening a process that is just, democratic, socially and economically profitable. That is why it is good for humanity as a whole and especially relevant to achieving the Millennium Goals, among which the fight against hunger, poverty and marginalization occupies a main place. And in that process, women, their empowerment and their equal position with men are decisive. And they are particularly so in rural areas, where women around the world are called to play an important role if their capacities and contributions are made visible and fully projected on productive activities. Today, in the developed world, but especially in developing countries, women face discrimination particularly intense in rural areas. United Nations reports estimate that changing this situation would increase the productivity of the primary sector by more than 30 per cent, an essential progress to meet the forecasts of population growth for the coming decades. This report therefore raises basic conditions for ending discrimination and specific measures focusing on rural areas and access to new technologies and the media, following the script proposed by the United Nations. The general conditions include intensifying work against violence against women, especially practices such as forced marriages or genital mutilation; furthermore, advancing the training, education and provision of universal and free social services to enable equal opportunities between men and women. An objective now weighed by a clear imbalance in the distribution of tasks that are linked to domestic logistics and care for children and the elderly. To promote women's professional performance in rural areas, we are committed to a status of professional women in rural areas, such as the one already in force in the Basque Country. Its basic pillars are access to ownership and ownership or co-ownership of farms and social security systems. Similarly, the establishment of specific funding channels to promote new activities and products; specific training that incorporates digital skills and modernizes and gives another dimension to the role of women in the creation of new products and their marketing; the progressive incorporation of women into the processes of decision, both in the public and private sectors, including from institutions to producer organizations of cooperatives and production and processing enterprises; and a compilation of statistical data, systematic and homogeneous, allowing the evaluation of the results of policies for full equality with this catalogue of measures. We are convinced that the consolidation of a status of professional women in rural areas that will promote, recognize and protect this equation is a conquest, not only for women, but of humanity. And this will be especially visible if this real revolution for justice and equality accelerates in developing countries. Madam President, with your generosity, I should like to add only one point: I regret that, among the outstanding news of this Parliament, once again such an important report has not been included, when it comes to equality for women in the world.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank Mrs Jourová, for her participation in this debate, as well as my colleague, co-rapporteur Izaskun Bilbao, for her excellent work and cooperation and all the work we have done together on this report; I would also like to thank the rapporteurs alternatives of the different groups. From the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, we are presenting this Parliament's recommendation to the Council for the next session of the UN Commission on the Law and Social for Women, which will start shortly in New York and in which a delegation from this Parliament will participate, in which we will be us. The priority theme of this session is the empowerment of women and girls in rural areas, and on this issue the co-rapporteurs decided to focus our report. It is estimated that more than 75 per cent of the population living in extreme poverty worldwide is in rural areas. Ninety per cent of countries in the world have at least one law limiting women's economic equality. Millions of girls in rural areas are deprived every day of the right to go to school because they have no access to drinking water or electricity, they are primarily responsible for looking for water or fuel for their families. To do this, they have to travel, in many cases, several kilometers, exposed, in addition, to sexual violence in their journey. To break the cycle of poverty, it is essential to promote the empowerment of rural women and girls through access to education, health and productive resources. That is why, in our report, we recommend that the Council, within the framework of the next session of the United Nations Commission, promote policies aimed at eradicating poverty and ensuring an adequate standard of living for particularly vulnerable groups, such as women and girls, especially through the social protection system; programmes to ensure that women and their families have access to universal social protection systems that impact their future retirement situation and thus contribute to bridging the multi-dimensional pension gap; access to universal and quality health care that is tailored to the needs of rural women and girls, in particular with regard to health and their sexual and reproductive rights; universal access to adequate care services for children and older persons in rural areas; that women and women and women rural girls can easily access credit and productive resources and are supported in their economic initiatives. We also recommend that it guarantee the property rights of rural women, in particular their right to own farms and to inherit land, which is a very important tool for their economic empowerment and enables them to participate fully in rural development and to benefit from condemn all forms of violence against women and ensure that none of the victims in rural and isolated areas are deprived of equal access to assistance and protection; to develop employment policies, services and programmes aimed at addressing precarious situations of rural women who, often, work in the informal sector and can face multiple forms of intersectional discrimination by sex, age, class, religion, ethnicity, disability or gender identity; provide assistance and support tailored to needs and interests; guarantee the fundamental human rights of migrant and seasonal workers and their families, especially women and girls, and to promote their integration into local communities; which would promote gender mainstreaming. And I just want to add that at a critical moment, when there is indeed a setback for the first time in decades in women's and girls' rights globally, we call on the European Parliament to support this Recommendation.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, later this month the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women will hold its 62nd session in New York. This year the priority theme is the empowerment of rural women and girls, while the review theme is participation in, and access of women to, the media and information and communication technologies and their impact on, and use as, an instrument for the advancement and empowerment of women. I am happy that, as in previous years, there will be an EU delegation representing the team of Europe led by my colleague, Neven Mimica, with Members of the European Parliament as part of the EU delegation. The position of women and the full enjoyment of their human rights by women and girls are still areas of concern for us in 2018. Progress on these topics is by no means a given. In fact, we have seen attempts to go backwards and to call into question once again the rights of women and girls, including in Europe. We discussed these questions thoroughly, together with many stakeholders, during the Annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights in November last year. In this global context, the EU is one of the world leaders in gender equality. We are by far the biggest investor. With the EUR 500 million EU-UN Spotlight Initiative, the latest commitment to collaborate with other international organisations in combating violence against women, a global alliance is being formed. And, to mitigate gender—based violence in humanitarian crises, the EU has taken over the leadership for the call to action on protection from gender-based violence in emergencies. Furthermore, the EU will strive for the session to adopt agreed conclusions that take into account the particular reality of rural women and girls world-wide, that challenge social norms and gender stereotypes, that promote equal economic independence for women and men, that promote women’s participation in decision—making at all levels, and that strengthen the prevention of all forms of violence against women and girls and the protection of its victims. I would like to thank Parliament for drafting such a comprehensive document that captures the priorities related to this year’s priority team very well. The Members of the European Parliament have an important role to play, complementary to that of the Member States and the other EU institutions. I am very happy to be here today, and I welcome this opportunity to listen to your views on priorities for the upcoming session.

name: President. –
text: I am aware that there are a lot of people who would like to contribute to the debate in catch the eye. However, I think that catch the eye is not possible because of the time constraints. I apologise to colleagues who would like to contribute, so please contribute in writing. I would ask those who now take the floor to adhere to their time please.

name: Dubravka Šuica
text: on behalf of the EUSR Group — Madam President, equality between women and men is a fundamental value of the European Union, which is also enshrined in the Treaty on European Union and is promoted as a fundamental priority in the Union's external activities. This topic “Challenges and opportunities in achieving gender equality and empowering women and girls in rural areas” at the 62nd session of the United Nations Council on the position of women is very important for me in order to eliminate inequality based on gender. Taking into account the increase in urbanisation of large numbers of families moving from rural to urban areas, it is very important to provide various and well-thought-out incentives for young women and families to develop and thrive in rural areas. One of these incentives must focus on equality between women and men since most women in the world live in rural areas, and so far there has not been enough debate about discrimination against women in such areas. We all know that education is important and that it plays a key role in every person's life. Full access to education must be provided to all women in rural areas for better quality of life, but also to eliminate the pay gap between men and women. We also need to take into account the climate change that we are witnessing, which most affects rural areas and women who live there. Even after decades internationally and not just at Union level, the gap between men and women remains large, especially in rural areas. Our Union must lead the fight against the inequality of women and men, and that is why I consider this recommendation a good material and I hope that we will continue in this direction and that the Union will continue to fight inequality.

name: President. –
text: Ms Grapini has requested a blue card but as time is short in this debate I am afraid I am not going to be able to accept any blue cards.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, today we are bringing to debate a resolution which aims to fix this Parliament's position on the position that Europe — in this case, the Council — must bring to the UN Commission on the Status of Women. The Assembly will discuss many issues and, above all, the specific situation of rural women in the world. I would like to thank Mrs Bilbao and Mrs Vallina for their work in generating a document that has emerged from the debate and the work of many and many of us who participate in these actions and which we believe it is essential to talk about the status of women in rural areas. We are talking about double discrimination against women in rural areas. We talk about difficulties in access to employment, issues related to gender-based violence, but also about the need to promote public services to ensure women's access to education or, for example, health and sexual and reproductive health rights. And in that regard, I would especially like to recall that today a year ago the SheDecides platform was launched, where hundreds of thousands of women and men cried out against the decision of the Trump administration which, at the time, was raising the cut of funds to organizations that are working on health rights sexual and reproductive rights. We talk about women's health, we talk about the health of girls, and we can not risk avoiding these dangers. Therefore, let us continue to be many voices for women's sexual and reproductive health rights around the world.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Among the European Union's priorities for the United Nations session in New York is strengthening the economic situation of women living in rural areas. I think we all know perfectly well that women in rural areas are particularly difficult. Very often doing the same physically hard work as men, they get lower pay. They have more difficult access to health care, education, education. It is very good that today we are talking about these things, because we can effectively improve the situation of women by facilitating access to education, health services, medical services, social care. We also need to talk about the fact that women should be guaranteed the right to a pension. These women whose lives are focused on caring for the elderly in the family, for the sick, for the children. So I will support all these priorities that I think are right, good and right. Without superfluous ideology.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, Mrs Jourová, the media and information technology show us how we look at ourselves, our own image as a society, and, when we look at them, we see too many stereotypes about men and women, that we continue to offer young people roles and visions of the past. The best initiatives for gender equality focus on combating prejudice among children and young people, on teaching equality and non-discrimination, telling girls that they can be what they want and that they can want the same as boys. But these initiatives struggle with a disadvantage in the face of media inertia, which continue to offer images and stories of highly sexualized women and girls or in traditional roles. The public observes how while a man is valued based on his experience or knowledge, the main thing is usually his physique of a woman. I think this has a lot to do with the organizational culture of the media and with the low presence of women in positions of responsibility. If this representation gap is present in all sectors, communication and new technologies will have much more sensitive consequences. That is why, with the utmost respect for freedom of expression, we must encourage greater involvement of the media in the defence of equality, which is the struggle of all, society as a whole.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, three proposals that concern women in rural areas today. The first question: we want protection from transnational corporations that occupy our land, our territories, often with a lot of violence and, moreover, to steal our natural resources and also our waters. Secondly, protection from industrial agriculture that destroys our jobs, pollutes, fumigates whole villages and expels us from our local markets and local markets. And a third question: the legal recognition of our rights as peasants through shared ownership laws that give us 50% of the income from the farm, 50% of aid, 50% of production rights, and also guarantee us a decent pension. And, in this regard, I would like to ask you, Commissioner — and in conclusion — to withdraw the pan-European income from individual pensions, which will cause a greater gap in rural women's pensions.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President! Would you imagine giving birth to babies in a car, 50 miles from the nearest midwife? It is forced women in Sollefteå in northern Sweden to do, due to the defunct of the maternity ward. The countryside has to live. It is a big problem that the differences between country and city are increasing. In my native Sweden, terrified first-time parents are forced to drive many miles to the nearest BB, and that is unworthy of a welfare country like Sweden. Service like health care and health care must be available to everyone regardless of where you happen to live. This report is about lifting the need for rural equality and women's needs there. Worldwide, women in rural areas face challenges that affect their lives and the opportunity to create a safe life of freedom. It is also important that the report lifts the need for climate justice and the situation of women in poorer countries. They must have their rights met with regard to the right to the earth they usually and the right to their own body. This is especially important given that women are important actors of change at the local level in tackling the impacts of climate change.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: — Commissioner, colleagues, the European Union must indeed be a leader in women's rights, empowerment and equal opportunities. In particular, with regard to rural women, we must give them as much access as possible to adequate education, to have a safe, well-paid job, to guarantee the right to high-quality healthcare and, of course, to combat all forms of violence against women, and at the same time ensure that women, even in the outermost areas, have equal access to the necessary assistance. Rural women's labour is very often less remunerated than the same work for men and is not even officially recognised, and I really call for women in rural areas to be able to move from the informal economy to the official and recognise that rural women work in different areas, and encourage more change by creating sustainable and environmentally friendly agriculture. It is also necessary to ensure full access to adequate childcare services in rural and rural areas.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this year the Commission on the Status of Women has chosen to focus on rural women, and rightly so. Women in rural areas are too often overlooked, despite their crucial role in their communities. They are more affected by climate change than men; they are more dependent on natural resources; and they play a significant role in ensuring food security for their communities. Their role in the fight against malnutrition is crucial, and their empowerment is necessary. I am happy to report that this report highlights the importance of women’s involvement in citizenship, but we must remember that fair political representation will never be achieved if girls’ human rights are not fulfilled. This means eliminating FGM, giving girls access to reproductive health and menstrual sanitary products, and fighting against rape culture, child marriage and all forms of gender-based violence. Later this month, I’ll join with colleagues to take our work to the United Nations in New York, but I am very concerned that Mr Trump’s administration has refused to grant visas to many women activists who planned to attend, and that this refusal is a way to silence the grassroots women’s movement. I therefore call on the EEAS and the Member States to use all diplomatic channels to help ensure that these attendees can obtain their visas.

name: President. –
text: Commissioner Jourová, you have heard from women about the status of women, so I invite you to respond.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, it has been a pleasure to hear your views and recommendations for the Council on the upcoming meeting of the Commission on the Status of Women and I am happy to see such strong commitment and I hope our levels of ambition will be met.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, thank you all for your contributions. I could end this debate by insisting on the measures we are proposing, disaggregating statistics. It could be a polite speech, right, but I think it's cold. Violence against women, discrimination, inequality deserve shock treatment. That's why I'm going to tell you about Ifé, a woman who once looked up at my personal blog in an entry that I dedicated to condemning the violent murder of a woman like her. Her name was Ada, no ax, no luck and no magic wand... Ifé is a sub-Saharan woman. For three years in a row he cried and desperated as he tried to survive in the first world, while saving to seek a better future in the third. Because although her shiny, smooth, black skin sometimes reflected neon, her every day were the red lamps that marked her ordeal. It was the semi-darkness. It was the dancer contract that allowed her to obtain a residence permit. It was the sinister choreography of domination, abuse, disrespect, dehumanization. They were the tickets he kept and they were the ones that that criminal took away after every night of “services”. Ifé cried a lot, but every tear reminded him that the alternative was to marry at the age of twelve to a much older man chosen by his father, pegón, rude; to suffer a dreadful mutilation to turn it into an object at the service of the lord of the house; to travel daily dozens of kilometers hunched under the weight of fifteen liters of water; breathe toxic smoke to transform what would go through waste here into a single meal a day; plow the earth with your nails; give birth a few children and watch die in half; go hungry; suffer, little by little, the loss of teeth, the shine of the eyes, the cracks in the skin; quench; end up cornered, at twenty-four, like a piece of furniture rickety and useless. A fair, human world with values continues to offer many rural women, like Ifé, the terrible choice between the bad and the worst. This report is a cry of rebellion against that reality and an attempt to change it. Getting it is everyone's responsibility.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, I would like to conclude by recalling that women and girls in rural areas are essential players in achieving poverty eradication throughout the world, ending hunger, promoting sustainable agriculture and achieving food security. Thank you very much for all the contributions. I think we are dealing with a consensus report, a co-presentation between the ALDE Group and the GUE/NGL Group in which both co-rapporteurs have worked to bring positions closer, first, between ourselves and then with the rest of the groups. That is why I would like to express to you again my appreciation for your contributions. And, at the moment, I ask you for a majority and determined support for the text of the report as adopted by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and which has as its priority to contribute to the empowerment of women and girls in rural areas.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the recommendation on the EU priorities for the 62nd session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women and the provisions provided within. I strongly share the opinion that we have to put the spotlight on the empowerment of rural women, as they are often the primary care providers in their families and communities. However, they are confronting numerous difficulties in accessing childcare and elderly care for their families, which generates a disproportionate burden on women and hampers their integration into the labour market. Finally, as also pointed out in the report, the fifth UN Sustainable Development Goal (SDG5) consists in achieving gender equality and empowering all women and girls throughout the world. Therefore, the Union and its Member States must step up their efforts and be at the forefront of the empowerment of women and girls. I would remind you that we have a duty to work towards the achievement of full gender equality in the Union, and to promote this goal in all external relations.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support the recommendation of the European Parliament presented to the Council for the 62nd session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. The EU could stand as one of the examples in terms of gender equality and therefore should be vocal in promoting those values across the world. We need to encourage all countries to further develop and implement policies to facilitate the lives of women and girls around the globe, and especially to prevent discrimination and domestic violence, to promote access to education and involvement in public life that mainly remain limited in rural areas, and to eliminate the gender pay gap and unfair conditions in employment. The entrepreneurial potential and economic benefit of full women’s participation in the labour market represents the underexploited source of economic development. We should urge the ratification and implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with a special focus on article 6 relating to the rights of women with disabilities, the Marrakesh VIP Treaty, and to pursue policies to address the situation of women facing social exclusion and poverty. Furthermore, the EU should call on the 18 remaining members of the Council of Europe to ratify the Istanbul Convention.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. — Gender equality and women's rights are things we discuss at European and national level, and yet in this century we still have discrimination against women, especially in rural areas. As stated in today's debate, 75% of the poor people live in rural areas. I congratulate the rapporteurs, but I believe that we will not solve this problem of gender equality if we do not invest in education, especially in rural areas. Then we should have specific measures to finance women who want to develop a business, but also for specific health care for women. I support the report, but it is important to supervise the implementation of the rules, rules and regulations approved at European and national level.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. – Female empowerment is becoming more and more important on the agendas of international organisations such as the UN, which is a great success. However, there is still a lot of work that needs to be done. I congratulate the rapporteurs for their work on the report. They touched upon important issues such as women’ accessibility to formal and informal education, especially in rural areas, the promotion of digital skills and the use of ICT. I believe that in this digital age the promotion of digital skills is the main solution to help women, especially those living in rural areas, to increase gender equality, reduce the wage gap between men and women, as well as to give women equal opportunities. Therefore, I encourage the creation of informal programmes such as Coder Dojo that we have here in Europe which encourages boys and especially girls to learn digital skills such as coding.
