We firstly have to change the attitude that ICT technologies are ‘only for boys’. It should not be covered by gender prejudices. I believe that access to ICT is the most effective way forward for female empowerment.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. — One of the fundamental principles of the EU is to respect and work towards greater equality between women and men. Over the past decades, social and economic circumstances and living conditions have changed considerably, thus working on improving the position of women and girls, and countering gender stereotypes, where the EU should be the front-runner. It is necessary to put an end to all forms of discrimination against women and girls worldwide and stand up to suppress all forms of violence that constitute serious violations of their fundamental rights, which are a direct consequence of that discrimination. All governments should develop programmes designed to eradicate sexual and gender-conditioned violence and harmful practices such as child, early and forced marriages, and women's genital mutilation and human trafficking. On the other hand, investment should be made in the education, lifelong learning and vocational training of women and girls, particularly in rural areas, particularly in the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and entrepreneurship and innovation, as these areas are an important tool for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, and to promote equality in the agricultural and food sector, tourism and other industries in rural areas.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The proposal for a European Parliament recommendation to the Council on the EU's priorities for the 62nd session of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women is important. The theme of the session is the challenges and opportunities for achieving gender equality and the empowerment of rural women and girls. Equality is one of the values underpinning the EU. The EU must actively promote equality between women and men, both within the EU and internationally. Impact through the UN is essential in this sector. Improving gender equality requires paying attention to a number of different sectors. Equitable, gender-independent access to healthcare, participation in education and decision-making are examples of areas in which gender equality can be improved. Education is a key factor effectively promoting gender equality in the long term. It is good that attention has been paid to the fact that climate change and its consequences are having a disproportionately negative impact on rural women and girls. The proposal states that there is a direct link between gender inequality and environmental degradation and that rural women can contribute to the transition to sustainable and ecologically sound agriculture. The environmental aspect is one of the reasons why gender equality should also be promoted in places other than our own neighbourhood. Measures to improve the status of women and girls are essential. The international debate must call for guaranteeing a reasonable standard of living and reducing poverty, increasing educational opportunities, eliminating gender discrimination and violence, and equalising the gender pay gap. People should have equal opportunities regardless of gender.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: in writing. — (NL) Mr President, until the 1960s, it was customary in the Netherlands for women to stop working when they married. Married women were even incapable of action. My own mother had to believe in it too: when she married, she was no longer allowed to stand in the classroom. Nowadays, this is no longer the norm, or the law. Yet we are still reaping the astringent fruits of that time. Mr President, we are now living in 2018, and yet here I am calling for an end to women's inequality. The numbers don't lie about it. In the Netherlands alone, income inequality between men and women is as much as 16.1%. Pension inequality is even greater, an embarrassing 44.9%. We are among the bad middlemoters, with a European average of 39%. Mr President, I call for equal pay for equal work here in Europe. This applies not only to Eastern and Western Europe, but also to men and women. Men and women are entitled to the same pay for the same work and therefore to the same pension. This way you can empower women by being financially independent. Close the pension gap. The Netherlands and Europe can do so much better.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Gender inequality poses serious threats to achieving a sustainable economy and reaching the goal of a non-discriminatory society. Moreover, the consequences of gender inequality are as serious as they are diverse, affecting girls and women in numerous ways, and especially women from rural areas. Figures show that the work of women from rural areas is often paid less than the work of men for the same output, and they encounter difficulties in getting access to adequate public health services. This situation is unacceptable for the Europe of the 21st century and calls for immediate action, which is why I support the recommendation of the European Parliament to the Council on the EU priorities for the 62nd session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. We need to focus more on the challenges women from rural areas face, in all Member States, and the key EU priorities to increase the participation of women to media, information and communication technology are vital for the advancement and empowerment of women. My view is that we must make extra, but concrete, efforts to achieve gender equality and I fully support the use of digital technology as an instrument to sustain these efforts.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. — In a few days, March 8, it is Women's Day. And beyond the words of 'equality', how does the European Union really celebrate it? With the recent ruling of the European Court of Justice releasing the dismissal of pregnant women in the context of collective redundancies, it is enough that it is not because of pregnancy, but for economic reasons. Foolery. Barbarism. For employers, the reason is that pregnancy and maternity do not keep up with profits, competitiveness. The work jungle of “private contracts” with prospective employees that they will not create a family, contracts that are not renewed when the employee becomes pregnant. Quotas per sex do not change the laws of capitalist exploitation, which use discrimination against women as a means of reducing wages and generalizing flexible work for profits. The Union's priorities are hostile to women's labour, insurance and social rights. Women's rights are jeopardised by judgments, Community directives and national legislation. And they are conquered only with their participation in the labor, popular movement.

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: Mr President! I asked for the floor because I would like to call once again for urgent urgency, namely the fact that you mentioned in your statement yesterday, namely the killing of the Slovak journalist. We have heard new facts in the European media today that, following the case in Malta and the case in Slovakia, unfortunately, two journalists have now been murdered in their commitment to freedom of expression. On the basis of urgency, because there is no COP meeting this week, I would like to ask us, as Parliament, to say that we are keen to an independent investigation in the case of Slovakia, that the facts are put on the table in order to achieve independence. Secondly, having reported in the public media today that EU funds may obviously have been abused, I would ask our CONT Committee to send its own fact-finding mission to Slovakia. The European Parliament must be the driving force to shed light on the incidents in Slovakia and to protect the independent journalists. I would ask that we as Parliament put this on the way. (Applause)

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: Mr President! I believe that this Parliament — and may I say this for my group — will not be surpassed by anyone when it comes to defending the rule of law and unreservedly investigating, investigating and getting to the root of all criminal incidents — serious incidents such as the killing of journalists. We are therefore also in favour of holding a debate here in due course, if the facts allow this. That, I believe, is also the consensus among the forces of the House. I would just like to remind you that this mission, which was proposed by Mr Weber, is on the agenda of the Taxe III Committee, is therefore already envisaged for the new committee of inquiry that we are also planning to launch today. I would ask the President to consult those responsible in TAXE III so that no duplication of effort is required. Otherwise, I would like to remind Mr Weber that we are studying everything without reservation. This applies to all the Member States of the European Union, irrespective of which head of government may be a member of the EPP at the moment. This will not prevent us from examining everything that needs to be investigated in a clear and radical way. This also applies to current allegations of corruption that have become loud in this context.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to stress that the murder of journalists should never become a question of party politics. It is too serious a matter. (Applause) This Parliament took tough action when this happened in Malta and we should do the utmost to take similar action when it happens in the Slovak Republic. Therefore I support the suggestion by Mr Weber to send an ad hoc mission to Slovakia, and to do so under the remit of the Conference of Presidents, because we cannot wait another few weeks until a secretariat has been created for the new committee: we have to act now. Journalists have the right to act freely in investigating corruption and taxation issues, and this Parliament should waste no time in safeguarding that right. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: I am also convinced that freedom of the press is neither a right, centre, nor left issue. Freedom of the press is a fundamental value for the whole of the EU and must be so for all governments, whatever colour they are. So I think the best solution is to start a written procedure today through the presidents of the political groups to decide to send a group of MPs, let's see in what formula, in Slovakia to ascertain what happened, so coma the commission “Panama Papers” went to Malta to see what was happening. I will propose a written procedure in the afternoon, so that no more time should be wasted. I must also tell you that three people have been arrested today: these are three Italian citizens who lived in Slovakia. But the problem is to understand not only who the material performers are, but who are the perpetrators of the murder. We still didn't quite understand who were the dispatches of the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia. As I said, I will continue to insist on this subject because we cannot lecture others if we don't look inside our house first. So I will proceed quickly with a written procedure so that all groups can formally express their will and it is possible to send this delegation of MPs as soon as possible.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, speaking on behalf of my colleague Alberto Cirio and others on Slovakia, we are presenting this question. President Weber has talked about funds, incorrect use, but there is also an incorrect use of relocation, internal dumping, and I am referring to the workers of the Embraco, who will be laid off, and the company could move from Italy to Slovakia. This is misuse, it is very serious that it happens within the regions of the European Union.

name: Presidente. –
text: I dealt directly with the affair because yesterday, accompanied by the president of the Piedmont Region, the workers and union representatives of the company in question came. I have already mobilized to try to give a concrete answer and I am in tune with the trade unions, with the president of the Region and also with the Italian authorities who are following the affair.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, you’re talking about Member States upholding the rule of law, and about the murder of journalists. And, given that we have Nils Muižnieks sitting here and going to address the House, I think it is important that we remember the murder, by loyalists, of human rights lawyer Pat Finucane and the fact it has been evidentially proven that there was British collusion in that murder. So here you have a Member State involved in the murder of a human rights lawyer – Pat Finucane.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we know and appreciate what you did yesterday and you will do about this very unbelievable situation on which, as you know, the efforts of the Italian Government converge in same direction: ask multinational companies that they have a sense of social responsibility. When they go to a country they invest, work, and they can't close for purely financial reasons, because they go away of their reputation and therefore it also becomes a detriment to them. I would just ask you that in the course of this assessment, which will also make the Committee on Budgetary Control with all the instruments we will have, we also consider the regional funds, the European funds that go to the less developed regions to grow, they are instead used to do this by dumping labour, social and tax. I think that, alongside all the actions we will do for this company, for the workers we have all received together, there is also this aspect of the use of European funds.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I have the honour to lead the mission to Malta and I would like to concur that indeed there is still more work to be done. We are waiting for an answer from the Conference of Presidents but, of course, the work to be done should be done under the remit of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and the new committee that is to be established following on from the Committee on Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion (PANA Committee). However, Mr President, what I wish to ask for now is that you should raise with the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy the situation in Ethiopia. Brutal repression is going on. The Government, including the Prime Minister, has resigned. A state of emergency has been re-imposed, and the statement made by the European Union is a shame by comparison with the one put out by the Americans condemning the reinstatement of the state of emergency. I ask you to bring this up with the Commission and with High Representative Mogherini. The European Union needs to take a position in the light of our values and the interests of democracy – which must be inclusive – in Ethiopia, as well as the re-establishment of the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Presidente. –
text: We are not having a discussion about human rights. There have been calls for action on urgent matters, but we have a guest, I think it is also our duty. We can intervene before the debate.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE).
text: – I ask you Mr President to now come to the agenda.  (Applause) Because on the issue we are discussing it fits very well to listen to Mr Muižnieks.

name: Presidente. –
text: This is what we are doing, but the story of the murdered journalist is so serious that even the Commissioner for Human Rights whom we invited, Mr Muižnieks, will have well understood the importance of the issue. I thank him for patienting for a few minutes, but there was also talk here about human rights. (The sitting was suspended at 11.48 a.m. Parliament meets at the address of Nils Muižnieks, Commissioner for Human Rights of the Council of Europe.)

text: The next item is the election of a Vice-President of the European Parliament to replace Mr Czarnecki. I would remind you that under Rule 20 of the Rules of Procedure, the new Vice-President takes the place of the outgoing Vice-President who replaces in the I received the nominations of Mr Krasnodębski, proposed by the ECR Group, and Mr Tarand, proposed by a number of Members equal to at least the low threshold. The candidates have told me that they accept the nominations. We will therefore proceed to the election with the secret electronic vote. - After the vote:

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I voted for a candidate on three occasions, and on three occasions the vote has been registered and then has disappeared. The system is not working.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission, in writing. – The Commission recalls that under the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making of 13 April 2016 the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed that in order to swiftly and correctly apply Union legislation in the Member States, the time limit for transposition of directives would be as short as possible and, generally, not exceed two years. In view of the particular timeframe for the application of Directive (EU) 2016/97 and of the Delegated Regulations adopted under this Directive, which resulted in difficulties for small and medium-sized insurance companies and insurance distributors to implement the required changes in time for the application date of 23 February 2017, the Commission exceptionally submitted a proposal to amend Directive (EU) 2016/97 by setting the date for application to 1 October 2016. The co-legislators have also agreed to postpone the transposition date for Directive (EU) 2016/97 to 1 July 2018. The Commission considers that this cannot be interpreted as creating a precedent, as it must be ensured that all Member States are treated equally, but notes that exceptionally it will not stand in the way of this agreement. The Commission expects Member States to fully comply with their obligation to bring their national transposition measures into force at this date at the latest, in order to give insurance companies and insurance distributors enough time to finalise their preparation and adaptation measures with the full knowledge of the European and national legislative frameworks.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, as a democrat I appreciate the decision of a parliament and very much welcome your vote in favour of the Belgian candidate.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to request that the matter be returned to the committee responsible for inter-institutional negotiations, in accordance with Rule 59 (4) of the Rules of Procedure.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This closes the voting time.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Madam President, honourable Members, today's regulation on the definition, presentation and labelling of spirit drinks, the use of spirit drink names in the presentation and labelling of other foods and the protection of geographical indications is an important step towards the development of sector. I am pleased that my proposal to preserve the linguistic diversity of the Union has been adopted and the right to this multicultural diversity will be protected. I am pleased that the Commission's initial proposal on the conditions for recognition of a new category has also been revised. The alcoholic beverage industry is already heavily regulated, so I believe that it should not be further aggravated and difficult. Geographical indications for spirits are also extremely important. I therefore think it is necessary for the legislation on spirit drinks to be as close as possible to that of agricultural foods and products. This will help the whole European Union to impose itself on the global market as a defender of local traditions, production and products.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: — Madam President, the protection of geographical indications for alcoholic beverages is very important, especially for countries which have traditional drinks such as Greece, drinks such as ouzo, tsikoudia and tsipouro. However, these traditional drinks must be bottled within the geographical area concerned. Moreover, as I pointed out to Mr Hogan yesterday, the reduced excise duty on raki and tsipouro must be maintained in Greece, because this is the only way that these traditional drinks can be protected. In this context, the Commission should withdraw its action against Greece, and where it is currently before the Court of Justice of the European Union, because, I repeat, this excise duty, reduced by at least 50%, must be maintained in order to ensure that this excise duty is reduced by traditional drinks, namely tsikoudia and tsipouro, to be able to really survive.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, some years ago I had a constituency case involving a fruit winemaker in Sussex. Fruit wine was redefined from being a spirit to a wine, so it suddenly fell within the EU’s directives on bottling. This guy – who employed, I think, eight other people – suddenly found that they had to change not just his bottles, but his labels, the cases, the prices and everything, because he was using 140 cl and 70 cl bottles rather than the mandated 150 cl and 75 cl bottles. Now, here’s the point: that winemaker was not exporting anything. There was no cross—border dimension. He was trading – like the majority of small and medium enterprises – in a fairly limited radius of where his business was situated. The problem with the way that the single market has evolved is that it no longer concerns itself only with issues of trade, but presumes to dictate to even the smallest and most local of businesses – and that reduces consumer choice and reduces economic growth.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — I supported this proposal, although I must say that I, too, see it as problematic if rules are prescribed to fall uniformly into a very limited market. Indeed, it is often burdensome for male producers, for the local regional economy, for local producers and farmers. On the other hand, this adjustment aims to avoid misleading practices on a general scale, ensure consumer protection and prevent unfair competition. These are the values I measured in my vote, and ultimately I decided to support this report, hence the draft legislation. To me, it is very important that the rules relating to spirits will apply uniformly and this is accompanied by the procedural rules on geographical labelling. We also have Žatecký hops in the Czech Republic, and we want this raw material to be protected in this way.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, mar rapóirtéir den ghrúpa INTA, ghlacas páirt sa díospóireacht a bhí againn ar an ábhar seo aréir, agus bhí sí suimiúil agus dar ndóigh bhí sí tábhachtach. Bhí áthas orm gur glacadh leis an tuarascáil le móramh mór anseo inniu mar is ábhar an-tábhachtach é agus go háirithe go bhfuil fás mór ag teacht ar bhiotáille á easpórtáil timpeall an domhain, dá bhrí sin tá sé tábhachtach go mbeadh gach rud ceart againn ó thaobh lipéad agus mar sin de. Tá blas draíochta ag baint leis na táirgí seo, go háirithe ó mo thír féin, agus táim an—bhródúil as sin.  Rud amháin a vótálas ina choinne ná beoir alcóil a bheith glactha mar bhiotáille. Is dóigh liom gur cheart idirdhealú a dhéanamh idir an dá rud agus bhí an Coimisiún ar an ábhar agus ar an bhfocal céanna aréir.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: Madam President, I join my colleagues in emphasizing the importance of this regulation. I am satisfied with what we have approved and with the mandate we are going to carry out from Parliament. I think there has been sensitivity to traditional methods; in the case of my country, with the “solera” method in Jerez brandy, which is very important. It was enshrined in Spanish legislation and we feared that it could not now be transferred to European legislation. I think that respect has been shown to traditional methods, which I welcome. But I would like to say that I voted against the introduction of nutritional profiles in this regulation. That is not to say that it is against the need to debate and advance nutritional profiles in alcoholic beverages, but, of course, this was not the regulation and this is not the right time. Hence my negative vote specifically on these amendments. I am satisfied with the general approval of this regulation.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Madam President, in 2017 alone, multinational companies exported profits of over EUR 600 billion. Tax havens take advantage of the increased mobility of capital and individuals in the internal market. We have come to have agreements that facilitate cross-border tax evasion and allow individuals and corporations to move their profits to tax havens. If the tax authorities do not cooperate with each other, then we will not resolve this situation. I also recommend the tax authorities to use the millions of documents and information from what investigative journalists have discovered — and I refer to Lux, Panama, Paradise Papers, Azerbaijan Laundromat and so on — because they all refer to tax havens and identifies politicians or other people who hid their money there. So states can recover their money using this information.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: — I find nothing new to this Parliament if I tell you that I am convinced of the need for rules which oblige governments and businesses to transparently provide all economic information. That is why we supported this text, because it is going in the right direction. Secret tax agreements between companies and Member States or tax dumping policies as a way of competing between Member States and other Member States do not contribute to generating any wealth, they only contribute to fraud and evasion and tax havens, as we are seeing on a permanent basis. I am convinced that the proposals along the lines in which they are made in this consultation are the way to combat tax inequality. We need more compulsory information, publicity in agreements between Member States and transnational corporations. Tax leaks must be covered with transparency and updated information in the short term. These proposals, made by the ECON Commission and supported almost unanimously, respond to all European citizens who expect us to react to their outrage.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I also supported this directive, because I feel that it is in the fight against tax evasion that the individual tax authorities of each national state can cooperate very intensively and is Europe, within its European law, should adopt clear rules for this, for cross-border cooperation of tax authorities. This is what colleagues said before, the problem of leaking money into tax havens is a big problem with the EU, and so we must respond to this with sufficient quality legislation. That is why I also supported this directive, and I hope that it will be used in practice, that it will be implemented into individual national legal adaptations and contribute to ensuring that between the individual tax the authorities of the Member States have had a compulsory exchange of information and that those seeking to establish, e.g., an establishment in a tax haven, must report such facts to the relevant tax authority.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, both in the report and in the debate we are being too loose in our language. When we talk about tax havens, and paradis fiscal, we are running together two things. One is something which is secret and therefore illegal, which not a single Member of this Chamber is going to defend. Of course it would be wrong for people to escape their legal responsibilities. The other is places that simply have lower tax rates than we would like – and those places, I would argue, are providing a service by providing some constraint on the appetites of less continent governments. This running together of tax avoidance and tax evasion, which runs through so many of these reports, is conflating two very different things. One is a serious criminal offence; the other is something that people do in the UK every time they buy an ISA or premium bonds, or any other legal device that reduces their tax exposure. If we in this House make that elision, how can we expect citizens to respect the difference?

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — To me, it is important that there will be an exchange of information to prevent tax fraud. Tax fraud is often done by white collar delinquency, i.e., very intelligent people taking advantage of every loophole, moving their taxable profits into tax havens, so the exchange information in that cross-border intercourse is very important. It is also important to preserve the issue of transparency. However, to unify direct taxes, I certainly would not be for that, so if it came to this report, this directive, I could support it, because I support the prevention of tax offences in various Member States, but if the Member States were to unify direct taxes, I would certainly oppose that. In this sense, I could therefore support this proposal for a directive.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Madam President! I voted against Parliament's resolution on the Commission's decision to trigger Article 7 of the Treaty in relation to the situation in Poland. This decision is not only an expression of the double standards used in the Union, but one more attack on the Polish government elected in democratic elections, which, according to its electoral promises, carries out a late reform of at least twenty years. This is especially about judicial reform, which the majority of the public has no confidence in. Reform of the functioning of justice in accordance with the Treaties is within the competence of the Member States. So concerned about the rule of law in Poland, the opposition, despite its long-standing rule, did not carry out any reforms, and only perpetuated previous pathologies. The solutions proposed by the Polish government are also used in other Member States, and different levels of retirement age are only an expression of respect for women and an appreciation of their work as wives and mothers who raise children.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Madam President! Of course, I voted against the disgraceful decision against Poland taken by the European Union or the European Parliament, which, incidentally, never wished to take action against mass police brutality and eye shootings. I also voted this way because I agreed with the resolution of the Hungarian Parliament of 21 February, which is entitled: on the stand for Poland against the pressure exerted by Brussels. I quote: In the forty years behind the Iron Curtain, we have had enough of dictates. Hungary and Poland have recently suffered a number of illegal and unjust attacks by the institutions of the European Union. Poland and Hungary believe in the Community of European Nations instead of the idea of the United States of Europe. Instead of spreading the idea of open society, we consider preserving our Christian culture as our task. The Parliament considers it unfounded that the European Parliament and the European Commission have initiated or decided to initiate proceedings under Article 7 of the EU Treaty against Poland.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Madam President! I would like to thank everyone voting against this shameful resolution, which is to strike Poland. Poland is a free and democratic country, we respect the rights of democracy and it is in democratic elections that Poles elected a parliamentary majority. This parliamentary majority, following the electoral programme, spoke of repairing Poland's unjust justice system, which was oppressive against the weak and powerless against the strong. We promised Poles that this system of injustice would become a system of justice. Our proposed solutions are the same with those that operate in many Member States. It is disgraceful that the European Parliament wants to engage in matters that it completely does not understand. We inherited the justice system, Madam President, from the Polish Republic, from the Soviet communist being.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Why should the European Parliament still have to refer to a possible request by the European Council to take steps against Poland with Article 7 but refer to the two-thirds majority provided for by the Treaties today? For what purpose? I guess just to have formal steps replaced by pure political demonstration. I guess to hide that the governments of European states are really stepping up against further dividing Europe in a situation where Europe already has so many problems. There really is something grotesque about the fact that at the moment we are talking so much about populism, in place of the formal procedure laid down by the treaties we are conducting a pure political demonstration to show the existence of a majority that is not a majority envisaged by law, that is, a majority required 22 governments of the European Union countries.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, what bothers me about this motion is not just the intrusiveness and the presumption about telling a sovereign country how to organise its internal affairs, it is the asymmetry that we see over and over again in this Chamber. Whenever a government is criticised for some domestic policy, you can bet that it is a government that is unpopular in this Chamber because it is patriotic, or because it stands up for its national interests, or because it refuses to endorse the goal of the United States of Europe.  This is a classic example: there were judicial reforms made by the previous Polish Government that resulted effectively in the packing of the bench, with not a peep of protest from this Chamber. But when the current Government undoes those reforms to try and restore a measure of balance to the judiciary, the sky falls in. All of you who voted for this measure know in your hearts that, if this had been a goody—two—shoes federalist government, this motion would never have come before the House.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: — Madam President, why do we want to punish Poland? Because it has limited the term of office of Supreme Court judges, as many States do. Because Poland — and this is a crime in the eyes of the majority of this Parliament — respects the life of the unborn child. Because Poland has a Conservative government, which is indeed its right. Because Poland, which has been a victim of German aggression, wants concentration camps on its territory to be called perhaps “camps in Poland” but not “Polish camps”, it seems to me to be the least. And we can see that the majority of this Parliament, supporting the Commission's maneuvers, gives the most cynical example of the tutelage which the Eurocracy wants to take against the freedoms of the peoples of Europe. I cried out as once, in the time of Napoleon III, a Frenchman in the passage of the Tsar: “Long live Poland, long live Poland”.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, if we cannot protect our principles inside the EU we will lose the moral right to criticise non-EU countries’ decisions. We should create independent evaluation mechanisms and strengthen sanctions for violations of EU fundamental principles within the Union. We have no choice. We have to understand whether we have common values or not. If not, the only possible decision is to dissolve the European Union. If yes, we must establish discipline among Member States and have the means to enforce it. Therefore, I welcome this motion for a resolution and I hope such discipline will be consistently applied. It is only through consistency in our policies on fundamental rights that we can achieve legitimacy in the eyes of our EU citizens. I voted in favour.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — I supported this motion for a resolution. In my opinion, the rule of law, democracy is not negotiated. The latter has clearly given rules — democratic rule of law. I remember very well when we discussed, it has been a number of months, the situation in Poland, which was directly involved in the Polish Prime Minister, she is no longer in office, she has been asked if she will respect the Polish government's award to be issued by the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe for assessing the constitutionality of the intended amendments precisely in the context of the dispute over the Constitutional Court. The Prime Minister avoided directly answering whether she would respect that opinion of the expert opinion of another organisation, the Council of Europe, not the EU. The judgment was absolutely overwhelming after it was issued by the Venice Commission, so I believe that we are supposed to have common values, that this is key at least in those bases. There is no negotiation on the rule of law, which is why I have nothing left other than to support this motion for a resolution.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: — Madam President, I voted against. Madam President! I voted against, albeit I agree that the ruling party has no idea what the rule of law is. Here, in the room Professor Legutko said they needed to remove judges who voted for commons and convict the opposition. But they were exercising the law, and so would today vote, just as PiS wants. However, they don't want judges who would apply laws, they just want judges who would vote at the whims of the ruling party. Judges in the new law will be punished and rewarded for how they vote, and that is, of course, against all principles of the rule of law. But I voted against, because any European Union interference meted out at PiS strengthens PiS. Any European Union attack on PiS rule strengthens PiS rule. That is why I am against this resolution and voted against. And besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this very important report. There is nothing more important than the upholding of the fundamental rights of citizens across the European Union. I want to speak today though, about a group of people who do not always see their fundamental rights upheld, and that is people with a terminal illness who sometimes find themselves facing a real challenge and difficulty in upholding their fundamental right to work. Yesterday we launched a new group in Parliament, of MEPs from across the House, to campaign for stronger legal protection for people with terminal illness in the workplace, and I am grateful for support from colleagues across the House for that group and for that cause. I would also call today on Parliament itself to sign our voluntary charter, to properly protect and support people in the workplace with a terminal illness, so everybody, across the EU, has that fundamental right to work properly upheld.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Madam President, on Monday, Slovak journalist Ján Kuciak and his fiancée Marina were shot. They were only 27 years old. Ján was an investigative journalist and worked with other colleagues on the investigation of cross-border drug crimes and ties to Slovakia. In October, Daphne Caruana Galizia was blown up with a bomb. We have two violent investigative journalists' crimes in the heart of Europe. Why? Because those journalists remained unshakable, because they wanted to tell the world the truth about the corrupt who govern us and all the evils and illegalities they commit and paid with their lives. Basically, the mafia organized itself to eliminate anyone who speaks freely and expose their corruption. Very briefly, I would like to say that we need to do a fact-finding mission in Slovakia, as we did in Malta.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Madam President! We Hungarians have again received a message from the European Union. I would like to pass it on to my compatriots in preparation for the elections on 8 April. This report on the situation of fundamental rights says: It stresses that the European Union - point 29, for the sake of interpreters - must promote inclusion and integration policies throughout its territory and considers it unacceptable for certain Member States to claim that it is not feel affected by the phenomenon of migration. Imagine, my compatriots at home, that those left-wing and liberal candidates who now claim that they will keep the fence on the border, they will keep the mass migration away if the Hungarian people demand it. How are they going to hit their parties, their party factions here, they really think they're going to be the great resistance here? Don't fall for that.

name: La Présidente. –
text: I would like to draw your attention, ladies and gentlemen, to the fact that we have to finish at 1.30 p.m. and that there are still a lot of explanations of vote to be made. So we will probably have to ignore the last ones, in any case orally.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: — Madam President, with the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2016, another document came to plenary, which in many respects brings the practice of gender identity contrary to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The report reiterates the subject of fundamental rights to ideological pressure on certain Member States, public opinion and the promotion of absurd social engineering. I refer to the problematic Article 70, which calls on the Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention. By ratification, pursuant to Article 6, the Contracting Parties, including Slovakia, would definitely undertake to quote: 'to incorporate the gender perspective into the implementation and assessment of the impact of the provisions of this Convention, 'the end of the quote. Combating violence against women is a clear duty of course, but it can also be effective other than by sacrificing other fundamental values, by accepting legal formulations that are incompatible with fundamental values and, above all, with the legal system of some Member States, to which we are entitled as sovereign and democratic states under EU law.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President! This report calls — in theory completely rightly — to avoid any abuse that may lead to the tyranny of the majority. Only the problem is that we live under this tyranny of the majority. Neither family nor life nor upbringing are treated as communities and goods whose natures have no right to change political power. The same goes for the freedom of nations. Against this freedom and contrary to the treaties, the current authorities of the European Union invoke, as President Timmermans says, the will of the vast majority of governments and this Parliament. So what is this appeal about? Is it really about the tyranny of the majority or maybe about to endure the last barrage that will protect our freedom, which is to enslave the public opinion of our nations?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - I did not vote for this report after all. Nevertheless, I would like to thank my colleague Frank Engel for trying to keep the message on a factual basis and focusing it on essential things such as combating discrimination, intolerance, racism and violence of all kinds, and of course also placed emphasis on protecting children on the internet. However, the problem is posed by the parts that propose greater support for sexual and reproductive rights, saying that these rights are related to fundamental human rights. I also find it problematic the proposals of the left that eventually got voted up and that invites flatly recognition of gay marriage. I must say that I voted to drop these parts, but there were a minority of us, and therefore I could not vote in favour of this report in the end, because I believe that these things should be decided Member States.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Madam President! March 1 is a special day for Poles — this is the National Day of Remembrance of the Soldiers of the Hatched. This is the day when we restore memory to the soldiers of the second conspiracy who, after the second world war, did not lay down their arms, only stand up to a heroic fight against the communist occupant. In 1944—56, nearly 50,000 soldiers of the independence underground were slaughtered in Poland, and 250,000 people were put into prisons. Another thousands were exported to Siberia and elsewhere in Russia. Close to 5 million Poles were surveillance during the Stalinist years. Unfortunately these actions proved successful enough that communist power survived until 1989 and it was this power that shaped the justice system in Poland, which today the Law and Justice government wants to reform, and unfortunately the dictatorship of the majority in the European Parliament that makes it difficult for him.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: — Madam President, the Engel report is a truly totalitarian report that calls any complaint from the minority as “hate speech” and “discourse of love, justice, charity, benevolence” the speech of the oppressive majority of these institutions. But shouldn't it be better to sweep outside his door? Would it not be better to ensure respect for the most basic rights in this institution, in this European Parliament? I take my personal example: at the request of Secretary General Welle, an official from the politicized circles of this House, I am taxed almost 300,000 euros, a huge sum. I am punctuated with three-quarters of the emoluments that should be used for my mandate for the perfectly grotesque reason that my assistant, for six years, worked not only with me but also with my colleague Jean-Marie Le Pen. Neither my assistant nor I, at any time, have been heard by Secretary-General Welle, by the Quaestors, or by the Bureau of which you belong. Start by respecting human rights within Parliament.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the report on the situation on fundamental rights in the EU in 2016. However, I would like to raise your attention to one thing: the rights of minorities in the EU are only a marginal topic in this report. I believe this is not a shortcoming of the report drafted by our colleague Frank Engel but rather a shortcoming of our policies. We actually do not have a real European approach to minorities, and we leave it to the discretion of Member States to protect them, but in some Member States minorities belong to really vulnerable groups. To give you one example, the Russian-speaking minority in Latvia is in decline due to emigration and to the negative birth rate. The death rate among Russian speakers in Latvia is much higher than the average in the country. The reasons for that are their unfavourable social conditions and the absence of rights for civil and political participation. These people are in a situation of total cultural insecurity and the reproduction of their identity is at high risk.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo, cinnte. Madam President, our fundamental rights must be rigorously upheld, and this report has carried out a thorough investigation and evaluation of that. The issues of hate speech, discrimination, migration and integration are especially relevant in our society, and we must learn how to combat division and animosity through the core values of the Union. I respect reports focused on protecting citizens and asylum seekers alike from violence and discrimination. We must continue to take into account the rights of minorities and communities throughout the EU, from ethnic groups to members of the LGBT+ community. The increased emphasis in the fight against organised crime and human trafficking is to be praised. I would also like to mention in that regard that we in the European Union should be making more noise and do more to bring attention to the appalling act of kidnapping by Boko Haram of 100 girls, and we must do everything we can to get them back.

name: La Présidente. –
text: I regret to inform you that we will not be able to take oral explanations of vote on the reports of Mr Sander Loones, Mr Nart and Mrs Bilbao Barandica and Mrs Vallina. Explanations of vote, of course, which may be tabled in writing. We have a time problem and we can't take them.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Madam President, what is in a jar of honey? In this jar – I am confident – it is pure honey produced by buzzing Suffolk bees and harvested by members of the West Suffolk Beekeepers’ Association that I had the pleasure of meeting last week. But honey is the third most adulterated product in the world. Twenty percent of samples taken on imported honey do not respect our high standards. Honey fraudsters add sugar syrup to their product or harvest it early and artificially dry it out to cut time and costs. They con consumers and endanger legitimate beekeeping with knock—on effects for the number of pollinators.  That is why I support this fight back with improved testing procedures, better labelling and higher penalties for fraudsters. Producing honey is hard work. This little jar of liquid gold represents the nectar from two million flowers so let us swarm to the defence of our hardworking bees and beekeepers.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — I would like to justify why I presented this report on the future of European beekeeping. For several reasons, mainly bees and plant pollination are crucial to sustainable agricultural production. Regardless, beekeeping products are in great demand in the EU. I think it is necessary to focus on those problems that we are able to influence with appropriate measures at European level as well. This is mainly the identification of cases of honey counterfeiting, which cause great harm to European beekeepers and pose serious health risks to consumers. At the same time, the amount of imported honey into the EU from China and third countries should be eliminated. In this context, I completely support the proposal to abolish the misleading designation of a mixture of honey from EU and non-EU countries and replace it with a clear indication of the specific country of origin.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to show my position in favour of this own-initiative report, to the great work that has been done, especially by my colleague Nekov, in our group. I think that a very comprehensive report has been made, and I hope that the European Commission will take advantage of it in order to tackle the serious problem of mortality in bees. This is a serious problem, and therefore it must be addressed seriously, with serious measures, in order to have a good response and not cause problems to the environment. But I would like to point out in my speech that the amendment proposed by a group of colleagues on the total ban on neonicotinoids, I think is not timely. We cannot make political decisions based solely on the influence, in it is not known what. That is, political decisions must be based on the results of scientific analysis, and I therefore very much agree with the view of EFSA, which partially prohibits some neonicotinoids.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Dear colleagues, European beekeepers have many challenges today and it is high time they were answered. I am pleased that we have adopted today's report because it is high time our beekeepers were heard. The main function of bees is pollination. This environmental service must be fairly rewarded and direct subsidies for pollination carried out by bees into the new CAP. A complete ban on the use of neonicotinoids, because it is high time this became a fact. Bee health has been deteriorating since the 1990s, in many regions they are dying, and European agriculture becomes monocultural. This trend has to stop. We are proposing a 50% increase in financial support for national beekeeping programmes, and this should be the minimum, and that needs to be done really very quickly. Imports from third countries are also a major challenge. Low-quality or cheap honey from countries such as China, Ukraine or Argentina suffocates European producers. The report is progressive and provides quite correct guidance for the development of the sector.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I was happy to support this report by my colleagues, who presented it on their own initiative. At first glance, it may look like the theme of beekeeping is a theme that is marginal. It is by no means that. My colleagues have already said this, the impact of this sector in the whole agricultural policy is extremely significant not only by the proportion and by employing our fellow citizens, but by the fact that pollination is the key thing that bees are securing right now. It's a good thing that the report describes current problems ranging from, say, bee colony diseases that lead to bee colony destruction, to problems associated with the single market. The issue of smuggling products that are called honey and honey are not, to Europe I think is a problem that is supposed to be addressed by the EU. It should be handled by some responsible EU institutions, the European Commission should address this. I was very surprised by the information that honey is the 2nd-3rd most commonly adulterated commodity on the market. It's a good thing the message has been received.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, fáiltím agus vótáil mé ar son na tuarascála seo mar is tuarascáil an-tábhachtach í. The fact that 76% of European food production depends on bee pollination shows how integral the species is to core aspects of humanity’s future. The destruction of European bee pollination by disease is of key concern. Therefore, it is essential that we support, educate and train more producers and the public, and commit to researching the challenges facing bees and the apiculture industry today.  We must support current beekeepers, many of whom have faced, or are facing, shutdown in business due to fake honey or decimated bee populations, and therefore I praise the recommendations for the revision of EU support for beekeepers. I especially hope this will be an integral part of the next common agricultural policy. The trends for beekeeping within the Union have been positive in recent years, and it is essential we maintain this upward momentum in order to preserve the apiculture sector for generations to come. Our future and the future of the planet depend on it.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Madam President! The EU's honey producers are in a rather unfair position because the current EU agricultural policy does not support their activities sufficiently, and they also have to deal with a significant amount of falsified honey in the internal market. This counterfeit quantity comes to a large extent from countries outside the EU and not only does it make our producers impossible, but also means misleading consumers. First of all, we must create favourable conditions for our own producers in order to ensure that EU consumers have healthy and quality honey, and we must change the current unfair competition situation. To this end, the Common Agricultural Policy after 2020 deserves special attention to honey producers, for whom it is necessary to establish a new direct support system and to introduce a tax exemption. EU citizens have the right to know what proportion of honey products they buy as honey contains honey from European producers, and their labelling needs to be adapted accordingly.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this is not fair. We waited and we prepared to speak and I think you should stay until the end. There are two more files for which we prepared to speak. It is less than ten minutes. It is on the list and now you cancel it. Really it is not fair for us.

name: La Présidente. –
text: Madam, I have indicated twice that we have a significant hourly constraint and therefore we would have to stop at 1:30 p.m. We stop at 1:36 p.m. and I think I actually warned. But your explanations are welcome. They will be collected in writing in the minutes of this sitting, there is no problem. I'm sorry, but we have this important constraint and we cannot overcome it.

name: La Présidente. –
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
